[[Maxine Waters]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, United States representatives from California, American political activists, African American politicians, Politicians from St. Louis, Missouri, US Democratic Party politicians, State legislators of the United States

Maxine Moore Waters (born  August 15, 1938) is an American politician. She is the U.S. Representative for CA, and previously the 35th and 29th districts, serving since 1991. She is a member of the Democratic Party, she is the most senior of the 12 black women currently serving in the United States Congress, and is a member and former chair of the Congressional Black Caucus.

[[Sarah Huckabee Sanders]]

CATEGORIES: 1982 births, Living people, White House Press Secretaries, Politicians from Arkansas, US Republican Party politicians, People from Hope, Arkansas

Sarah Elizabeth Huckabee Sanders (born August 13, 1982) is an American political aide. Sanders was the 29th White House Press Secretary from July 26, 2017 to July 1, 2019. She served as Deputy White House Press Secretary from January through July 2017.

Sanders announced her resignation as Press Secretary on June 16, 2019 and left the office on July 1.

Sanders is the daughter of former Governor of Arkansas and presidential candidate Mike Huckabee, and former Arkansas first lady Janet Huckabee.

On January 25, 2021, Sanders announced her candidacy for Arkansas Governor in the 2022 election.

[[Claude Rich]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from prostate cancer, Cancer deaths in France, French movie actors, French television actors, French stage actors

Claude Rich (8 February 1929 – 20 July 2017) was a French actor and screenwriter. He was born in Strasbourg, France. He began his career in the theater before his movie debut in 1955. His best known roles were in Season's Beatings, With a Little Help from Myself, and in Looking for Hortense.

Rich died on 20 July 2017 in Orgeval, France of prostate cancer at the age of 88.

[[Geoff Mack]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from dementia, Disease-related deaths in Australia, Australian guitarists, Australian singer-songwriters, People from Victoria (Australia)

Albert Geoffrey "Geoff" McElhinney OAM (20 December 1922 – 21 July 2017), better known as Geoff Mack, was an Australian country singer-songwriter. He was awarded a Medal of the Order of Australia on 13 June 2005 with the citation, For service to country music and to the community,through support for senior citizens' groups. As a songwriter, he wrote "I've Been Everywhere" which was an Australian hit for Lucky Starr in April 1962. More than 130 cover versions have been recorded.

Mack died on 21 July 2017 in Benowa, Gold Coast, Australia of dementia-related complications at the age of 94.

[[Ashleigh and Pudsey]]

CATEGORIES: People from Northamptonshire, 1995 births, Living people, 2005 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from blood cancer, British entertainers, Dogs

Ashleigh and Pudsey were a British dog trick act, comprising trainer Ashleigh Jade Butler (born 7 February 1995) and Pudsey (28 December 2005 – 21 July 2017). Pudsey was a male Border Collie, Bichon Frise and Chinese Crested powderpuff cross. 

They first achieved prominence as contestants in the sixth series of the television talent show Britain's Got Talent, which they won on 12 May 2012, becoming the first ever dog trick act to win the competition. On 21 July 2017, Ashleigh announced that Pudsey had died.

Pudsey died on 21 July 2017 of blood cancer at the age of 21.

[[Deborah Watling]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Cancer deaths in England, English television actors, English movie actors, Actors from Essex

Deborah Watling (2 January 1948 – 21 July 2017) was an English actress. She was born in Loughton, Essex. She was known for her role as Victoria Waterfield, a friend of the Second Doctor in the BBC television series Doctor Who.

Watling died on 21 July 2017 from lung cancer in Frinton-on-Sea, Essex at the age of 69.

[[Bernhard Kempa]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2017 deaths, Coaches, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, Disease-related deaths in Germany, German sportspeople, People from former German territories

Bernhard Kempa (19 November 1920 – 20 July 2017) was a German handball player and coach. He became world champion in field handball in 1952 and 1955 as a national team player. He was born in Opole, Upper Silesia. Kempa made a significant contribution as the outstanding player. 

Until his career as a player in 1957, Kempa won the championship in Göppingen one more time in the hall (1955) and in the field (1957). As a Göppinger coach, he did so in the indoor handball five more times (1958-1961, 1970), and Kempa also took the Europapokal in 1960. 

In 2011, Kempa was admitted to Germany's Sports Hall of Fame.

Kempa died in Bad Boll, Germany of complications from Parkinson's disease on 20 July 2017 at the age of 96.

[[America's Morning Headquarters]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 American television series debuts, The Weather Channel shows, English-language television programs

America's Morning Headquarters, often called AMHQ, is a morning television program on The Weather Channel.  It was formerly named Your Weather Today and Morning Rush.

AMHQ airs live from Atlanta, Georgia from 5 to 9 a.m. Eastern Time on weekdays. The show gives current weather information for Americans. A weekend edition, called AMHQ Weekend, was started on January 31, 2015.

[[Artigas Department]]

The Artigas department (Departamento de Artigas) is a department of Uruguay. The capital is the city of Artigas.

Its ISO 3166-2 code  is UY-AR.

[[Anthony Scaramucci]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, American political writers, White House Communications Directors, Businesspeople from New York, Politicians from New York, Writers from New York, US Republican Party politicians

Anthony Scaramucci (born January 6, 1964) is an American entrepreneur, financier, political figure, and author. On July 21, 2017, President Donald Trump appointed him the White House Communications Director, but before he could take office, he was removed from the position by President Donald Trump on July 31, 2017, at the request of the White House Chief of Staff, John Kelly.

In June 2017, he became a senior vice president and chief strategy officer at the U.S. Export-Import Bank.

[[Penza]]

CATEGORIES: Capital cities in Russia

Penza is a city in the Penza Oblast, Russia, 388 mi southeast of Moscow. The city has 522,823 people.

[[Yami Lester]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Australia, Australian people, Activists

Yami Lester (1942 – 21 July 2017) is an Australian Yankunytjatjara man, an Indigenous person of northern South Australia. He was born in Lester, who survived nuclear testing in outback Australia is best known as an anti-nuclear and Indigenous rights advocate.

In the 1950s, while still a young boy, he was blinded by a "black mist" from the south. His actions helped lead to the McClelland Royal Commission in 1985, which found significant radiation hazards still existed at the Maralinga test sites.

Lester died in Alice Springs, Australia from complications of a stroke on 21 July 2017 at the age of 75.

Serra do Salitre is a municipality in the northwest of the Brazilian state of Minas Gerais.

Neighboring municipalities are: Cruzeiro da Fortaleza and Lagoa Formosa(N); Rio Paranaíba (E); Ibiá and Perdizes(S); Patrocínio (W).

[[Davos]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities of Graubünden, Ski areas and resorts in Switzerland, Cities in Switzerland

Davos (Tavau, Tavate) is a ski resort and municipality in the district of Davos in the canton of Graubünden in Switzerland. The ice hockey club EHC Davos has a stadium in the town.

Davos is the host town of the yearly World Economic Forum meeting.

[[Sword of Grossenwieden]]

CATEGORIES: Swords

The Sword of Grossenwieden is a sword that was found in Germany, in 2012. Scientists believe that it was made at the workshop that built Ulfberht swords that were not fake.

The sword was found in gravel from the river Weser, at Grossenwieden, which is part of the city Hessisch-Oldendorf in Niedersachsen. Die Gefäßteile the guard and pommel  contains sheet metal (en:) containing an alloy of tin and lead. The lead seems to originate from a source that mostly was emptied during the Age of the Romans.

The weight is close to one kilogram.

[[Noryangjin station]]

CATEGORIES: Railway stations in South Korea, 1899 establishments, Establishments in South Korea, 1890s establishments in Asia

Noryangjin Station is a train station of Gyeongbu Line, and subway station of Seoul Subway Line 1 and Line 9. Noryangjin Station was first opened as station of Gyeongin Line, the first rail line in South Korea.

At first opening, the station was temporarily in location of Yeongdeungpo Station, and moved to present location at July 8, 1900, as opening of Gyeongseong Station section.

Anna Netrebko (born 18 September 1971) is a Russian operatic soprano. She was the People's Artist of Russia (2008).

[[Timothy Goes to School]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 television series debuts, 2001 television series endings, 2000 establishments in the United States, 2000s establishments in Canada, 2001 disestablishments in the United States, 2001 disestablishments in Canada, English-language television programs

Timothy Goes to School was a Canadian-Chinese animated children's television series based on the books by Rosemary Wells and was produced by Nelvana. The series originally aired on TVOKids in Canada and PBS Kids as part of the PBS Kids Bookworm Bunch in the United States. The series follows a young on Nick Jr. in Canada raccoon named Timothy and his friends at Hilltop School.

[[John Heard]]

John Matthew Heard (March 7, 1946 – July 21, 2017) was an American movie and television actor.

[[Hrvoje Šarinić]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from cardiopulmonary arrest, Prime Ministers of Croatia

Hrvoje Šarinić (xr̩̂ʋoje ʃǎrinit͡ɕ; 17 February 1935 – 21 July 2017) was a Croatian politician. He served as the Prime Minister of the Republic of Croatia from 1992 until 1993. After the parliamentary elections of 1992 he, as member of Croatian Democratic Union (HDZ), was appointed to the post of prime minister.

Šarinić died on 21 July 2017 in Zagreb of cardiopulmonary arrest at the age of 82.

[[Kostiantyn Sytnyk]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2017 deaths, Ukrainian politicians, Scientists, Communists, Legislative speakers

Kostiantyn Merkuriyovych Sytnyk (Костянтин Меркурійович Ситник; 3 June 1926 – 22 July 2017) was a Ukrainian and Soviet scientist and academician. 

Sytnyk was a member of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine. In 1970-2003, he was director of the Botanic Institute of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine. Sytnyk also is politician and served as the Chairman of the Verkhovna Rada of the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic from 1980 to 1985.

Sytnyk died on 22 July 2017 in Kiev, Ukraine at the age of 91.

[[Air raid]]

CATEGORIES: Military tactics, Military terminology

An air raid is an attack in which bombs are dropped from aircraft on to a ground or sea target. 

If the area has a civil defense system, operators may send a air raid alert to warn people. It may be a siren or a radio broadcast. People hearing the alert try to go to an air raid shelter for protection. The same warning system may send an "all clear" signal when the danger is over.

[[Jim Vance]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from lymphoma, Cancer deaths in Washington, D.C., American television news anchors, American journalists, Writers from Pennsylvania, Writers from Washington, D.C.

James Howard "Jim" Vance III (January 10, 1942 – July 22, 2017) was an American television news anchor in Washington, D.C..

In 1972, Vance became WRC-TV's main co-anchor, as one of the first African Americans to serve in this position at any American television station.  Between 1972 and 1976, Vance worked as co-anchor with Glenn Rinker at WRC-TV. Between 1976 and 1980, Vance co-anchored with Sue Simmons, a pairing that resulted in one of the first, if not the first, African-American co-anchors of a major market newscast.

Vance died on July 22, 2017 in Washington, D.C. following a short battle with non-Hodgkin lymphoma at the age of 75. At the time of his death, Vance was the region's longest-serving television news anchor with more than 45 years at WRC-TV.

[[Paul Coffey]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, Boston Bruins players, Canadian ice hockey coaches, Canadian ice hockey defencemen, Carolina Hurricanes players, Chicago Blackhawks players, Detroit Red Wings players, Edmonton Oilers players, Hartford Whalers players, Hockey Hall of Fame inductees, Ice hockey people from Ontario, James Norris Memorial Trophy winners, Living people, Los Angeles Kings players, Ontario Hockey League players, Philadelphia Flyers players, Pittsburgh Penguins players, Sportspeople from Toronto, Stanley Cup champions

Paul Douglas Coffey (1 June 1961) is a Canadian retired professional ice hockey defenseman who played for nine teams in the NHL. He was born in Weston, Toronto, Canada.

[[Fei]]

CATEGORIES: 1987 births, Living people, Chinese singers

Wang Fēifēi (hangul: 왕페이페이; hanja: 王 霏霏; born April 27, 1987 in Haikou) better known by her stage name Fei, is a Chinese singer, actress and TV presenter. She debuted as a member of miss A in 2010 under the company JYP Entertainment. In 2016, she made his debut as a solo artist with his CD single titled Fantasy.

[[Lotus (album)]]

CATEGORIES: 2012 albums, Christina Aguilera albums, Pop albums, Electropop albums, R&B albums

Lotus is the seventh studio album by American singer Christina Aguilera. RCA Records released the album on November 9, 2012.

[[Stubbs (cat)]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 births, 2017 deaths, Individual cats, Mayors, History of Alaska

Stubbs (April 12, 1997 – July 21, 2017) was an American cat who was the mayor of Talkeetna, Alaska from July 1997 until his death in July 2017. Until early 2017, Stubbs was still mayor, and has been described as a tourist attraction.

At least one opinion writer for the Alaska Dispatch News insisted that the whole story was false, and that Talkeetna, Alaska, did not, in fact, have a cat mayor. According to NPR, the cat could not have been elected as a write-in candidate because "the tiny town has no real mayor, so there was no election."

Stubbs died on July 21, 2017 in Talkeetna at the age of 20 years.

[[František Ševčík]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2017 deaths, Czechoslovak ice hockey players, Deaths from spinal cancer, Olympic silver medalists

František Ševčík (January 11, 1942 – July 22, 2017) was a Czech ice hockey player. He played for the Czechoslovak national team. He won a silver medal at the 1968 Winter Olympics. He was born in Vilémovice, Bohemia and Moravia, Nazi Germany.

Ševčík died in Prague, Czech Republic on July 22, 2017 from complications of spinal cancer at the age of 75.

[[Artyom Tarasov]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Russian businesspeople, Russian politicians, Political activists, People from Moscow

Artem or Artyom Mikhaylovich Tarasov (Артём Миха́йлович Тара́сов; July 4, 1950 — July 22, 2017) was a Russian businessman and political activist of Armenian descent. He was born in Moscow. In 1989 Tarasov became the first officially declared millionaire in the USSR. Tarasov is the co-founder of Kommersant daily newspaper, the first independent airline, Transaero, and was elected to the Russian parliament.

After a conflict with Soviet officials in 1990, he left the USSR and settled in London. In 1993, he returned to Russia and was once again elected to the Russian Duma. In 1996, he decided to run for President as an independent pro-business candidate, but his application was rejected by the electoral commission.

Tarasov died on July 22, 2017 from pneumonia at the age of 67.

[[Lau Wong-fat]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, People from Hong Kong, Chinese businesspeople, Politicians

Lau Wong-fat ('劉皇發), GBM, GBS, JP (15 October 1936 – 23 July 2017) was a Hong Kong businessman and politician. He had been the long-time chairman of the Heung Yee Kuk, the most powerful organ representing the interests of the New Territories  indigenous inhabitants from 1980 to 2015. He was also a member of the Legislative Council of Hong Kong from 1985 to 2016.

From 2009 to 2012 he was a non-official member of the Executive Council of Hong Kong. He had also served as the member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference and chairman of the Regional Council and the Tuen Mun District Council.

Lau died on 23 July 2017 in Tuen Mun, Hong Kong at the age of 80 after a long battle with Parkinson's disease.

He was made Justice of the peace in 1973. In 1981, he was awarded Member of the Order of the British Empire (MBE) and the Officer of the Order of the British Empire (OBE) in 1989.

[[The 411]]

CATEGORIES: English R&B bands, Musical groups established in 2003, 2000s British music groups, 2008 disestablishments in England, Musical groups from London, Musical groups disestablished in 2008, 2003 establishments in England, Musical groups disestablished in 2005, 2005 disestablishments in England, Musical groups established in 2007, 2007 establishments in England

The 411 were an English female R&B group formed in late 2003. The band sang backup vocals on Lemar's cover of Al Green's "Let's Stay Together". The band took its name after the 1992 Mary J. Blige album What's the 411?. During their time together as a group, they released one studio album Between the Sheets and three top-forty singles before breaking up in 2005.

[[Snooty]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2017 deaths, Individual animals, Florida

Snooty (July 22, 1948 – July 23, 2017) was an American male Florida manatee that lived at the South Florida Museum's Parker Manatee Aquarium in Bradenton, Florida. 

Snooty was one of the first recorded captive manatee births, and at age 1948, he was the oldest manatee in captivity, and was likely the oldest manatee in the world. Due to his hand rearing from birth, Snooty was never released to the wild and was the only manatee at the museum's aquarium that had regular human interaction. 

On July 23, 2017, one day after his birthday, Snooty died at the South Florida Museum at the age of 69.

[[Flo Steinberg]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from intracranial aneurysm, Deaths from lung cancer, Cardiovascular disease deaths in New York, Cancer deaths in New York, Publishers, Businesspeople from Boston, Massachusetts, Businesspeople from New York

Florence "Flo" Steinberg (March 17, 1939 – July 23, 2017) was an American publisher of one of the first independent comic books, the underground/alternative comics hybrid Big Apple Comix, in 1975. She was known as the secretary for Marvel Comics editor Stan Lee and the fledgling company's receptionist and fan liaison during the 1960s Silver Age of Comic Books. She was a key person of and witness to Marvel's expansion from a two-person staff to a pop culture conglomerate. She was born near Boston, Massachusetts.

As of 2007, Steinberg, who has appeared in fictionalized form in Marvel Comics, speaks at comic book conventions and has been the subject of a magazine profile.

Hardee's should not be expected to handle early arrival staging for Wal-Mart.

Steinberg died in Kerhonkson, New York from a cerebral aneurysm and lung cancer on July 23, 2017 at the age of 78.

[[József Szendi]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2017 deaths, Hungarian Roman Catholics, Roman Catholic archbishops

József Szendi (31 October 1921 – 23 July 2017) was a Hungarian prelate of the Roman Catholic Church. At the time of his death he was the oldest living bishop from Hungary. Szendi was born in Székesfehérvár, Hungary. 

Szendi was ordained a priest on 24 December 1944. From 1969 until 1982, he was spiritual of the seminary of Esztergom. Szendi was appointed Apostolic Administrator of the Archdiocese of Veszprém as well as Titular bishop of  Stephaniacum on 5 April 1982 and was consecrated bishop on 21 April 1982 by Laszlo Paskai. 

Szendi was appointed archbishop of the Archdiocese of Veszprém on 3 September 1983 and served until retiring on 14 August 1997.

[[Al G. Wright]]

CATEGORIES: 1916 births, 2020 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, American centenarians, American conductors, American educators, Musicians from London, Musicians from Indiana

Alfred Geoffrey "Al" Wright (June 23, 1916 – September 5, 2020) was an American bandleader and conductor. He was the Director of Bands Emeritus at Purdue University and Chairman of the Board of the John Philip Sousa Foundation. He was born in London, but his family moved to the United States in the 1920s. 

Wright became director of the Purdue All-American Marching Band (AAMB) in 1954, becoming only the second person to hold the position, and served for 27 years until his retirement in 1981. 

Wright and his wife Gladys live in West Lafayette, Indiana. He turned 100 in June 2016. Wright died on September 5, 2020 at the age of 104.

[[Barmas]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Iran, East Azarbaijan Province

Barmas is a village in Azghan Rural District, in the Central District of Ahar County, East Azerbaijan Province, Iran. At the 2006 census, its population was 215, in 49 families.

[[For Life]]

CATEGORIES: Exo albums

For Life is the fifth extended play of the South Korean boy band EXO. It is scheduled to be published on December 19, 2016 at 12am (KST) by S.M. Entertainment and distributed by KT Music. The EP contains five songs, including the single of the same name, in the Korean and Mandarin versions.

[[Udupi Ramachandra Rao]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Cardiovascular disease deaths in India, Indian scientists, Karnataka

Udupi Ramachandra Rao, popularly known as U. R. Rao (10 March 1932 – 24 July 2017) was a Indian space scientist. He served as Chairman of the Indian Space Research Organisation from 1984 through 1994. He was the Chairman of the Governing Council of the Physical Research Laboratory at Ahmedabad and Nehru Planetarium at Bengaluru and Chancellor of Indian Institute for Space Science and Technology (IIST) at Thiruvananthapuram. He was born in Adamaru, Karnataka.

Rao died on 24 July 2017 in Indiranagar, Bangalore of heart failure at the age of 85.

[[Wally Westlake]]

CATEGORIES: 1920 births, 2019 deaths, Pittsburgh Pirates players, St. Louis Cardinals players, Cincinnati Reds players, Philadelphia Phillies players, Cleveland Indians players, Baltimore Orioles players, Sportspeople from California

Waldon Thomas Westlake (November 8, 1920 – September 7, 2019) was an American utility baseball player. He had a ten-year career from 1947 to 1956. He was born in Gridley, California.

Westlake played for the Pittsburgh Pirates, St. Louis Cardinals, Cincinnati Reds and Philadelphia Phillies of the National League, and the Cleveland Indians and Baltimore Orioles of the American League. He played third base and outfield.  

Westlake was the oldest living former National League player, and was the oldest living member of the Cincinnati Reds, Philadelphia Phillies, Pittsburgh Pirates, and St. Louis Cardinals. 

Westlake died on September 7, 2019 at the age of 98.

[[Red Schoendienst]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2018 deaths, St. Louis Cardinals players, San Francisco Giants players, Milwaukee Braves players, Sportspeople from Illinois

Albert Fred "Red" Schoendienst (ˈ; February 2, 1923 – June 6, 2018) was an American Major League Baseball (MLB) coach, and former player and manager.

[[Gil Coan]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2020 deaths, San Francisco Giants players, Minnesota Twins players, Baltimore Orioles players, Chicago White Sox players, Sportspeople from North Carolina

Gilbert Fitzgerald Coan (May 18, 1922 – February 4, 2020) was an American professional baseball outfielder. He was born in Monroe, North Carolina.

Coan played in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the Washington Senators, Baltimore Orioles, Chicago White Sox and the New York Giants. He batted left-handed and threw right-handed. Before his death in 2020, he was the oldest living former New York Giants player.

Coan died on February 4, 2020 in Hendersonville, North Carolina. He was 97.

[[Omar Graffigna]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2019 deaths, Argentine generals, Argentine politicians

Omar Domingo Rubens Graffigna (2 April 1926 – 9 December 2019) was an Argentine Air Force officer. He served in the second military junta of the National Reorganization Process dictatorship. Alongside Reynaldo Bignone, he was one of the last surviving members of the dictatorship.

On 8 September 2016 he was sentenced to 25 years' imprisonment for crimes during the dictatorship.

Graffigna died in Buenos Aires on 9 December 2019 at the age of 93.

[[Bob DeMoss]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2017 deaths, American football players, American football coaches, Sportspeople from Kentucky, Sportspeople from Indiana

Robert Alonzo "Bob" DeMoss  (January 27, 1927 – July 23, 2017) was an American football player, coach, and college athletics administrator.  He served as the head football coach at Purdue University from 1970 to 1972, compiling a career college football record of 13–18. He was born in Dayton, Kentucky.

DeMoss played football as a quarterback at Purdue from 1945 to 1948.  He was then selected in the second round of the 1949 NFL Draft by the New York Bulldogs, from whom he played in 1949. 

DeMoss died at his home in West Lafayette, Indiana on July 23, 2017 at the age of 90.

[[Zootopia]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 animated movies, 2016 comedy movies, 2010s adventure movies, 2010s criminal comedy movies, 2010s mystery movies, Disney animated movies, Computer-animated movies, Academy Award winning movies, American adventure movies, American animated movies, American buddy movies, American comedy movies, American family movies, American mystery movies, Golden Globe Award winning movies, Movies about animals, Movies that won the Best Animated Feature Academy Award, Annie Award winners

Zootopia (also known as Zootropolis) is an American computer-animated comedy-adventure movie that was released on March 4, 2016 in the United States. It was made by Walt Disney Animation Studios as its 54th movie, and it was released by Walt Disney Pictures. The movie made over a billion dollars in the worldwide box office and became one of the highest-grossing movies of 2016. Zootopia won the Academy Award, Golden Globe, Critics' Choice Movie Award and Annie Award for Best Animated Feature Film.

The movie is about a police rabbit named Judy who has to solve a hard mystery, and has Nick, a red fox, for her assistant. Judy at first does not like Nick, but the two get along and then work together to solve the case. The movie takes place in a world of mammals, but there are no humans.

[[Gutland]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Luxembourg

The Gutland (Luxembourgish: Guttland) is the middle and the south of Luxembourg. It is about two-thirds of the country. About 90 percent of the people in Luxembourg live here (about 540,000 people).

The Gutland has low hills with an altitude of 200 to 300 meters.

The Gutland used to be Grevenmacher and Luxembourg Districts, and also the very southern parts of the Diekirch District.

[[Oesling]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Luxembourg

The Oesling in French or the Ösling in German (Luxembourgish: Éislek) is the north of Luxembourg. It is about one-third of the country. About 10 percent of the people in Luxembourg live here (about 60,000 people).

The Oesling belongs both to the Ardennes and the Eifel. It has medium hills with an altitude of 400 to 500 meters. Highest hill is the Kneiff with an altitude of 560 meters, and also the highest hill of Luxembourg.

The Oesling used to be Diekirch District, except for the southern parts of the Redange Canton, the Diekirch Canton, and the Vianden Canton.

[[Carrollton, Texas]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Texas, Settlements in Dallas County, Texas

Carrollton is a city of Texas in the United States.

[[Hop and Go]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 movies, Looney Tunes, English-language movies

Hop and Go is a 1943 Looney Tunes short movie directed by U.S. Corporal Norman McCabe and released to movie theaters by RKO Radio Pictures. It stars Mel Blanc.

[[Arrondissement of Belfort]]

CATEGORIES: Arrondissements of France

The arrondissement of Belfort is an arrondissement in the Bourgogne-Franche-Comté region of France. It is the only arrondissement of the Territoire de Belfort department.

[[Norman McCabe]]

CATEGORIES: 1911 births, 2006 deaths, Deaths from liver cancer, American animators

Norman McCabe (February 10, 1911 – January 17, 2006) was an American animator, cartoonist, and director. He is famous for creating animated cartoons during the Golden Age of Hollywood. He did his most major work for the Warner Bros. studios. He created the characters of Porky Pig and Daffy Duck. His had an effect on almost all of the animated cartoon series by various studios in the 1940s.

[[Hobby Horse Laffs]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 movies, Looney Tunes, English-language movies

Hobby Horse Laffs is a 1942 Looney Tunes short movie directed by U.S. Corporal Norman McCabe and released to movie theaters by RKO Radio Pictures. It stars Mel Blanc.

[[Porky Pig]]

CATEGORIES: Looney Tunes characters, Comics characters, Fictional characters introduced in the 1930s, Fictional pigs

Porky Pig is a cartoon character from the Warner Bros. cartoons. He stands on two legs, has a pink body, and a pink nose. He first appeared in I Haven't Got a Hat in 1935.

[[Bert Rossi]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2017 deaths, Criminals from London

Umberto "Bert" Rossi (1 November 1922 – 2 July 2017) was an English gangster and former associate of the Kray twins. He was known as the "General of Clerkenwell". He stood trial for murder in 1975 but was acquitted. He was a journalist linked him to 11 murders, a figure which he did not dispute. He was born in Clerkenwell, London, England.

Rossi died on 2 July 2017 in London at age of 94.

[[Howard Eichenbaum]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2017 deaths, American psychologists, Deaths from surgical complications, Jewish American academics, Jewish American scientists, Neuroscientists

Howard B. Eichenbaum (October 16, 1947 – July 21, 2017) was an American psychologist and neuroscientist of Jewish descent. 

He studied the hippocampus. He was a university professor and director of the Center for Memory and Brain at Boston University, having previously worked at Wellesley College. He was the editor-in-chief of the scientific journal Hippocampus.

Eichenbaum died on July 21, 2017 in Boston, Massachusetts from complications of back surgery at the age of 69.

[[Mervyn Rose]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2017 deaths, Australian tennis players, Sportspeople from New South Wales

Mervyn Gordon Rose AM (23 January 1930 – 23 July 2017) was an Australian male tennis player who won 7 Grand Slam titles (singles, doubles and mixed doubles). 

Rose was born in Coffs Harbour, New South Wales and turned professional in 1959. He was ranked inside the world's Top 10 throughout much of his tennis career and represented Australia in the Davis Cup from 1951 to 1957. He was ranked World No. 3 in 1958 by Lance Tingay of The Daily Telegraph.

He coached numerous female and male players, including Billie Jean King, Margaret Court, Ernie Ewart, Michael Fancutt, Brett Prentice, Arantxa Sánchez Vicario, Eleni Daniilidou, Nadia Petrova, Magdalena Grzybowska and Caroline Schnieder.

Rose was awarded the Australian Sports Medal in 2000, inducted into the International Tennis Hall of Fame in 2001 and the Australian Tennis Hall of Fame in 2002. He was appointed a Member of the Order of Australia (AM) in 2006 for service to tennis, particularly as a competitor at national and international levels and as a coach and mentor to both amateur and professional players. 

Rose died on 23 July 2017 at the age of 87.

[[Michiko Inukai]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2017 deaths, Writers from Tokyo, Asian philanthropists, Roman Catholics

Michiko Inukai was a Japanese Roman Catholic author and philanthropist. She was the founder of the Michiko Inukai Foundation, which provides financial aid for refugees seeking education.

Inukai was the granddaughter of Prime Minister of Japan Tsuyoshi Inukai.

Her first book Ojosan Horoki was published in 1958, and she has since written essays about Bible and Christianity. Her bestseller Hanabana to Hoshiboshi to was featured in a TV drama in 1978.

Inukai started charity in 1979. In 1983, she founded the Michiko Inukai Foundation to provide aid for refugees and internally displaced people in collaboration with the Jesuit Refugee Service.

[[Jørgen Kosmo]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Norwegian politicians, Mayors

Jørgen Hårek Kosmo (December 5, 1947 – July 24, 2017) was a Norwegian politician. He was born in Fauske, Norway. From 2005 to 2013 he was Auditor General of Norway, after representing the Labour Party in the Storting (parliament) for 20 years, of which the final 4 years as President of the Storting.

Kosmo was Minister of Defence from 1993 to 1997 and Minister of Labour and Government Administration from 2000 to 2001. Kosmo was in 2004 appointed County Governor of Telemark, but could not take over the position while he was member of parliament. From 1979 to 1985 he was member of the municipal council of Horten, the last 2 years as mayor.

Kosmo died in Oslo, Norway on July 24, 2017 of pancreatic cancer at the age of 69.

[[Emomali Rahmon]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, Living people, Presidents of Tajikistan, Current national leaders

Emomali Rahmon (Эмомалӣ Раҳмон, Emomalî Rahmon/Emomalī Rahmon; born 5 October 1952) is a Tajikistani politician. He has served as President of Tajikistan (or its equivalent post) since 1992. His rule is commonly regarded as a dictatorship.

During the early years of his presidency, Rahmon faced a civil war in which up to 100,000 people died. In 2013, he was elected to a fourth term in office.

[[Savoureuse]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of France, Bourgogne-Franche-Comté

The Savoureuse is a river in eastern France; it is the principal river running through the Territoire de Belfort.

[[Charlemagne Péralte]]

CATEGORIES: 1886 births, 1919 deaths, Haitian people

Charlemagne Masséna Péralte (1886 - 1 November 1919) was a leader in Haiti. He stood against the US Invasion of his country in 1915. He led fighters called the Cacos against the US forces in Haiti. The US needed to get more soldiers because Peraite was difficult to stop.213 Péralte is a hero in Haiti today.

[[Inukai Tsuyoshi]]

CATEGORIES: 1885 births, 1932 births, Assassinated people, Deaths by firearm, Prime Ministers of Japan

Inukai Tsuyoshi was a Japanese politician, cabinet minister, and Prime Minister of Japan from 13 December 1931 to 15 May 1932.

On 15 May 1932, Inukai was shot by eleven junior Navy officers (most were just turning twenty years of age) in the Prime Minister's residence in Tokyo.  

[[Steppenwolf (comics)]]

CATEGORIES: DC Comics characters

Steppenwolf is a fictional supervillain appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics. The character was created by Jack Kirby and made his first appearance in New Gods #7 (February 1972).  Steppenwolf (which is German for "wolf of the steppe", or coyote) is one of the New Gods,  the uncle of the archvillain Darkseid.

Steppenwolf is an immortal with superhuman strength, speed and stamina appropriate to his race. He is an experienced military leader. His main weapon is his electro-axe.

The character made his first movie appearance in Zack Snyder's Justice League movie, portrayed by Irish actor Ciarán Hinds.

[[Martian Manhunter]]

CATEGORIES: DC Comics aliens, DC Comics superheroes, Fictional characters introduced in the 1950s, Fictional shapeshifters, Fictional twins

The Martian Manhunter (J'onn J'onzz) is a fictional superhero appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics. He was created by writer Joseph Samachson and designed by artist Joe Certa. The character first appeared in the story "The Manhunter from Mars" in Detective Comics #225 (Nov. 1955). Martian Manhunter is one of the seven original members of the Justice League of America. 

J'onn J'onzz has featured in other DC Comics-endorsed products, such as video games like Injustice: Gods Among Us, television series, animated films, and merchandise like action figures and trading cards. The character was ranked #43 on IGN's greatest comic book hero list.

[[Black Canary]]

CATEGORIES: DC Comics superheroes

Black Canary (also known as Sara Lance) is the name of two fictional superheroines appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics: Dinah Drake and Dinah Laurel Lance along with rebooted amalgam version within The New 52. The original version was created by the writer-artist team of Robert Kanigher and Carmine Infantino. The character debuted in Flash Comics #86 (August 1947).

One of DC's earliest super-heroines, Black Canary has appeared in many of the company's flagship team-up titles including Justice Society of America and Justice League of America. Since the late 1960s, the character has been paired with archer superhero The Green Arrow professionally and romantically.

Black Canary has been adapted into various media. In Birds of Prey she was played by Rachel Skarsten, and in Smallville she was played by Alaina Huffman. In Arrow and the Arrowverse shows the characters Dinah Laurel Lance, Sara Lance, and Dinah Drake are portrayed by Katie Cassidy, Caity Lotz, and Juliana Harkavy. Dinah Lance made her cinematic debut in the DC Extended Universe film Birds of Prey, portrayed by Jurnee Smollett-Bell.

IGN rated her its 81st-greatest all-time comic book hero. She was number 26 on Comics Buyer's Guide's "100 Sexiest Women in Comics" list.

[[Captain Marvel (DC Comics)]]

CATEGORIES: DC Comics superheroes, DC Comics adapted into movies, Fictional characters introduced in 1939

Captain Marvel, also known as Shazam (ʃ), is a fictional superhero appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics. Artist C. C. Beck and writer Bill Parker created the character in 1939. His main villains are Doctor Sivana and Black Adam.

Captain Marvel first appeared in Whiz Comics #2 (cover-dated Feb. 1940), published by Fawcett Comics. He is the alter ego of Billy Batson, a boy who, by speaking the magic word "SHAZAM" (acronym of six "immortal elders": Solomon, Hercules, Atlas, Zeus, Achilles, and Mercury), can transform himself into a costumed adult with the powers of superhuman strength, speed, flight, and other abilities. 

Based on book sales, the character was the most popular superhero of the 1940s, outselling even Superman.

Zachary Levi  played Shazam! in the 2019 DC Extended Universe movie Shazam!.

[[Black Manta]]

CATEGORIES: DC Comics supervillains

Black Manta (David Hyde) is a fictional supervillain appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics. The character first appeared in Aquaman #35 (September 1967) and is the archenemy of the superhero Aquaman.

The character made his movie debut in the James Wan Aquaman movie, played by Yahya Abdul-Mateen II.

[[Gorilla Grodd]]

CATEGORIES: DC Comics characters

Gorilla Grodd is a fictional supervillain appearing in American comic book published by DC Comics. He was written as an enemy of The Flash. The character first appeared in The Flash #106 (May 1959) and he was created by John Broome and Carmine Infantino. Gorilla Grodd is an evil and super-intelligent gorilla who gained mental powers after being exposed to the radiation of a meteorite.

IGN named him 35th of the Top 100 Comic Book Villains.

[[DC Extended Universe]]

CATEGORIES: Fictional universes, Series of movies, DC Extended Universe movies, Warner Bros. movies, Media franchises

The DC Extended Universe (DCEU) is an American media franchise and shared universe that is centered on a series of superhero movies, distributed by Warner Bros. Pictures, based on characters that appear in publications by DC Comics.

[[Aquaman (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2018 movies, DC Extended Universe movies, Movies with underwater settings, Warner Bros. movies, 2010s superhero movies, Movies set in deserts, Movies set in 2018, American superhero movies

Aquaman is a 2018 American superhero movie based on the DC Comics character of the same name. Distributed by Warner Bros. Pictures, it is the sixth movie in the DC Extended Universe (DCEU). The movie was directed by James Wan, from a screenplay by David Leslie Johnson-McGoldrick and Will Beall and stars Jason Momoa as Aquaman, with Amber Heard, Willem Dafoe, Patrick Wilson, Dolph Lundgren, Yahya Abdul-Mateen II, and Nicole Kidman in supporting roles. In the movie, Aquaman sets out to lead the underwater kingdom of Atlantis, replacing his half-brother, King Orm, who seeks to unite the seven underwater kingdoms against the surface world.

[[Mera (comics)]]

CATEGORIES: DC Comics characters

Mera (ˈ) is a fictional character appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics. She was developed by Jack Miller and Nick Cardy. The character first appeared in Aquaman #11 (September 1963) as a queen of the sea. Mera was ranked 81st in Comics Buyer's Guide's "100 Sexiest Women in Comics" list.

American actress Amber Heard will portray Mera in the upcoming live-action movie Justice League, directed by Zack Snyder,and will return in Aquaman, directed by James Wan.

[[Geoff Johns]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, Living people, American comics writers, American television writers, American movie directors, American movie producers, Writers from Detroit, Michigan

Geoff Johns (born January 25, 1973 in Detroit, Michigan) is an American comic book and television writer, movie producer, and television producer. He is the president and Chief Creative Officer at DC Comics since 2010.

His most notable work in different media has used the DC Comics characters Green Lantern, Aquaman, The Flash, and Superman. He is known for his work on The WB/The CW's Smallville, Arrow and The Flash.

Johns is also a comic book retailer who co-owns Earth-2 Comics in Northridge, California with Carr D'Angelo and Jud Meyers.

In 2016, Johns was made the co-runner of the DC Extended Universe, and co-chairman of DC Films in order to create a unified vision and overarching story for the franchise.

[[Yahya Abdul-Mateen II]]

CATEGORIES: Living people, 1986 births, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American architects, Actors from New Orleans, Louisiana

Yahya Abdul-Mateen II (born 1986) is an American actor. He is best known for his role Cadillac in the television series The Get Down. He also starred in Baywatch (2017). He also appeared in The Greatest Showman and DC's Aquaman as Black Manta.

Abdul-Mateen was born in New Orleans, Louisiana. Before acting, Abdul-Mateen was an architect.

[[Sinestro]]

CATEGORIES: DC Comics supervillains, Fictional characters introduced in 1961

Thaal Sinestro (θ) is a fictional supervillain appearing in American comic books published by DC Comics. Sinestro is a former Green Lantern Corps member who was dishonorably discharged for abusing his power. He is the archenemy of Green Lantern and founder of the Sinestro Corps, though he occasionally has acted in anti-heroic roles as well.

The character was created by John Broome and Gil Kane, and first appeared in Green Lantern (vol. 2) # 7 (August 1961).

In 2009, IGN ranked Sinestro as the 15th Greatest Comic Book Villain of All Time.

Mark Strong portrays Sinestro in the live-action movie Green Lantern.

[[The Wizard (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1989 comedy movies, 1989 drama movies

The Wizard is a 1989 American adventure comedy-drama family movie. It was directed by Todd Holland. It was written by David Chisholm. It stars Fred Savage, Christian Slater, Jenny Lewis, Beau Bridges, and Luke Edwards.

The movie is about three children travelling to California. The youngest of the three is a genius in video games. The Wizard is famous for its extensive product placement of video games for the Nintendo Entertainment System. The MOVIE was also famous for being North America's introduction to one of the best-selling video games of all time, Super Mario Bros. 3.

[[Mark Esper]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, Living people, American lobbyists, American military people, Civil servants, Colonels, US Republican Party politicians, United States Secretaries of Defense, United States Secretaries of the Army, Harvard University alumni

Mark Thomas Esper (born April 26, 1964) is an American lobbyist and former government administrator for the United States Department of Defense. Esper is the 27th and current United States Secretary of Defense since July 2019. He was the 23rd United States Secretary of the Army from November 2017 until July 2019. He served as Vice President of government relations at Raytheon.

Esper studied at United States Military Academy, Harvard University and at George Washington University.

On July 19, 2017, it was announced that President Donald Trump had the intention of nominating Esper to become U.S. Secretary of the Army. He is Trump's third nominee for the position, following the withdrawals of Vincent Viola and Mark E. Green. He was confirmed by the Senate on November 15, 2017. He resigned on June 24, 2019 to become acting Defense Secretary.

President Donald Trump announced on June 18, 2019, that Esper would become acting Secretary of Defense. Three days later, Trump nominated Esper to serve the job full time. On July 23, 2019, his nomination was confirmed by a vote of 90–8.

On November 5, 2020, shortly after the 2020 presidential election, it was reported that Esper had prepared a letter of resignation from his position as Secretary of Defense. He was fired by President Trump four days later on November 9.

[[Joe Morton]]

CATEGORIES: Emmy Award winning actors, 1947 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Actors from New York City

Joseph Thomas "Joe" Morton, Jr. (born October 18, 1947) is an American actor. He worked with movie director John Sayles in The Brother from Another Planet (1984), City of Hope (1991) and Lone Star (1996). He is also known for his role as Lt. McMahon in the 1994 action movie Speed.

In 2014, Morton won the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Drama Series for his role as Eli Pope in Scandal. He is also known for playing the role of Henry Deacon on the popular TV series Eureka.

In 2016, Morton played Dr. Silas Stone, father of Victor Stone/Cyborg, in a cameo role in Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice as part of the DC Extended Universe. He will play the role again in the upcoming Justice League (2017).

[[Sausage Party]]

CATEGORIES: 2016 animated movies, 2016 comedy movies, American animated movies, American comedy movies, Adult animated movies, Dystopian movies

Sausage Party is a 2016 American adult 3D computer animated written and directed by: James Cameron, Steven Quale And Andrew  Stanton and development music by Hans Zimmer, Thomas Newman Steve Jablonsky and Rupert Gregson-Williams development Illumination Entertainment adventure and comedy movie. It was a spoof of Disney and Pixar movies.

Arizona is a state in the southwestern United States.

[[Belt and Road Initiative]]

CATEGORIES: Transport in the People's Republic of China

The Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), also known as the New Silk Road, is a plan by the government of the People's Republic of China to build infrastructure for transportation, from China to other countries in Asia, Europe, and Africa. The project was announced in 2013. The "Belt" means the roads and railway tracks on land. The "Road" means sea routes.

At first, it was called "One Belt, One Road" (OBOR, Chinese: 一帶 一路 / 一带 一路, pinyin: Yidai Yilu).

A high-speed railway in Thailand is part of OBOR; the Bangkok-Phitsanulok High-Speed Railway is under construction (as of 2017).

[[Yash Pal]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from lung cancer, Cancer deaths in India, Indian educators, Indian scientists

Yash Pal (26 November 1926 – 24 July 2017), also known as Yash Pal Singh, was an Indian scientist, educator and educationist. He was known for his works to the study of cosmic rays, as well as for being an institution-builder. In his later years, he has become one of the leading science communicators of the country.

Starting his career at Tata Institute of Fundamental Research (TIFR), he later remained chairman of the University Grants Commission from 1986 to 1991. In 2013, he was awarded India's second highest civilian honour, the Padma Vibhushan.

Pal died of lung cancer on 24 July 2017 in Noida, Uttar Pradesh at the age of 90.

[[Supreme Leader Snoke]]

CATEGORIES: Star Wars characters

Supreme Leader Snoke is a fictional character in the Star Wars franchise. He was introduced in the 2015 movie Star Wars: The Force Awakens. He is a CGI character voiced and performed by Andy Serkis.

Snoke is the leader of the First Order, an organization brought back from the fallen Galactic Empire, which wants to reclaim control of the galaxy. Powerful with The Force, he has seduced Kylo Ren to become evil and eventually led to him killing his father Han Solo. 

Snoke also appeared in Star Wars: The Last Jedi where he bridge the minds of Rey and Kylo Ren in order to manipulate them. Kylo Ren kills Snoke and takes his place as leader of the First Order. In Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker it is revealed that Snoke is a clone and a puppet of the resurrected Emperor Palpatine.

[[Paul D. Boyer]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 2018 deaths, Deaths from respiratory failure, Disease-related deaths in Los Angeles, American atheists, American educators, American biochemists, Scientists from Utah, People from Provo, Utah

ChemistryPaul Delos Boyer (July 31, 1918 – June 2, 2018) was an American biochemist, analytical chemist, and a professor of chemistry at University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA). 

Boyer shared the 1997 Nobel Prize in Chemistry for research on the "enzymatic mechanism underlying the biosynthesis of adenosine triphosphate (ATP)" (ATP synthase) with John E. Walker, making Boyer the only Utah-born Nobel laureate; the remainder of the Prize in that year was awarded to Danish chemist Jens Christian Skou for his discovery of the Na+/K+-ATPase.

In 2003 he was one of 22 Nobel Laureates who signed the Humanist Manifesto.

Boyer died two months shy of his 100th birthday in Los Angeles, California on June 2, 2018 of respiratory failure.

[[Kujataa]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Greenland

"Kujataa is a sub-arctic farming landscape in the southern region of Greenland".

The first known example of agriculture (or farming) in the Arctic is at Kujataa.

The oldest trace of the spreading of the Old Norse culture outside Europe is at Kujataa.

[[Bucyrus, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Ohio, County seats in Ohio

Bucyrus is a city in the U.S. state of Ohio. It is the county seat of Crawford County.

[[Crawford County, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: 1820s establishments in Ohio, 1826 establishments in the United States, Ohio counties

Crawford County is a county of Ohio in the United States. In 2010, 43,784 people lived there. The county seat is Bucyrus.

[[Cuyahoga County, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: 1810 establishments in Ohio, Ohio counties

Cuyahoga County is a county of Ohio in the United States. In 2010, 1,280,122 people lived there. The county seat is Cleveland. It was named after the Cuyahoga River.

[[Stark County, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: 1800s establishments in Ohio, 1809 establishments in the United States, Ohio counties

Stark County is a county of Ohio in the United States. In 2010, 375,586 people lived there. The county seat is Canton.

[[Greene County, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: 1803 establishments in Ohio, Ohio counties

Greene County is a county of Ohio in the United States. In 2010, 161,573 people lived there. Its county seat is Xenia. It was named for General Nathanael Greene, an officer in the Revolutionary War.

Mahoning County is a county of Ohio in the United States. In 2010, 238,823 people lived there. The county seat is Youngstown.

Campbell (ˈ; KAM) is a city in Mahoning County, Ohio, United States. The population was 8,235 at the 2010 census.

[[Befotaka]]

Befotaka is a town in Atsimo-Atsinanana Region in south-eastern Madagascar. It is near the Itomampy river.

[[Sogndal]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities of Norway

Sogndal is a municipality in Norway. It is in Sogn og Fjordane county. It is on the northern shore of the Sognefjorden in the traditional district of Sogn. The village of Sogndalsfjøra (population 3,455 in 2012) is the administrative center of Sogndal municipality. Other villages include Kaupanger, Kjørnes, Fimreite, Nornes, and Fjærland.  Sogndal Airport, Haukåsen is 10 southwest of Kaupanger.

In 1917, a farmer in Sogndal plowed up the Eggja stone, a gravestone with runic inscriptions important for the history of the Old Norse language.

[[Degen, Switzerland]]

Degen is a former municipality, in the new municipality of Lumnezia and the district of Surselva in the canton of Graubünden in Switzerland.

Disentis/Mustér (Disentis, Mustér) is a municipality of the district of Surselva in the canton of Graubünden in Switzerland.

Le Vaud is a municipality in the district of Nyon in the canton of Vaud in Switzerland.

Tatabánya (ˈtɒtɒbaːɲɒ) (Totiserkolonie) is a city in northwestern Hungary. It is in the Central Transdanubian region. It is the capital of Komárom-Esztergom County.

[[Fessenheim]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Haut-Rhin

Fessenheim is a commune. It is found in the Haut-Rhin department of eastern France.

[[Lost in Space]]

CATEGORIES: American science fiction television series, 1965 television series debuts

Lost in Space is an American science fiction TV series which was created by Irwin Allen and produced at the 20th Century Fox studios. It ran on CBS from 1965 until 1968, making three seasons with a total of 83 episodes. Its first season was made in black-and-white while its second and third seasons were made in color. The show stars Guy Williams, June Lockhart, Mark Goddard, Marta Kristen, Billy Mumy, Angela Cartwright and Jonathan Harris. The show's music was composed by Johnny Williams.

[[BMW Z4]]

CATEGORIES: BMW, Sports cars

The BMW Z4 is a rear-wheel drive sports car by the German car maker BMW. It is part of a line of past BMW roadsters such as the BMW Z1, BMW 507, BMW Z8, and the BMW Z3. The Z4 replaces the Z3. First generation production started in 2002 to replace the BMW Z3 introduced in 1995, at a plant in Greer, South Carolina, of BMW US. Both roadster and coupe versions of the car were made.

The Z4’s body dimensions were larger and its wheelbase was longer and wider. The suspension was also upgraded to be stiffer and the car was equipped with a sport package which firmed up the steering.

When it came out, it won Automobile magazine's "Design of the Year Award". With the 2009 model year, BMW started making the second-generation Z4 at BMW's Regensburg, Germany plant as a retractable hardtop roadster. In 2009, the BMW Z4 II won the Red Dot Design Award.

[[Carl von Ossietzky]]

CATEGORIES: 1889 births, 1938 deaths, German Nobel Prize winners

PeaceCarl von Ossietzky (3 October 1889 – 4 May 1938) was a German journalist and peacemaker. He was awarded the 1935 Nobel Peace Prize because he exposed the secret German re-armament. He was convicted of treason and spying afterwards.

[[David Copperfield (illusionist)]]

CATEGORIES: American magicians, 1956 births, Living people, Emmy Award winners, Television personalities from New Jersey

David Seth Kotkin (September 16, 1956), known professionally as David Copperfield, is an American illusionist. He is described by Forbes as the most commercially successful magician in history. Copperfield's career of over 40 years has earned him 11 Guinness World Records. Copperfield has won a total of 21 Emmy Awards. He has a star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame. Copperfield was knighted by the French government. He has also been named a Living Legend by the US Library of Congress. Copperfield was born in Metuchen, New Jersey, United States.

[[David Copperfield (disambiguation)]]

David Copperfield is a novel written by Charles Dickens. "David Copperfield" can also mean:

[[Barbara Sinatra]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from natural causes, Disease-related deaths in California, American models, American philanthropists, Entertainers from Missouri, Frank Sinatra

Barbara Marx Sinatra (née Blakeley; March 10, 1927 – July 25, 2017) was an American model and showgirl. She was born in Bosworth, Missouri. She was married to Zeppo Marx from 1959 to 1973 and was the fourth and final wife of Frank Sinatra from 1976 until his death in 1998. 

In 1998, a Golden Palm Star on the Palm Springs Walk of Stars was dedicated to her.

Sinatra died on July 25, 2017 in Rancho Mirage, California of natural causes at the age of 90.

[[Gretel Bergmann]]

CATEGORIES: 1914 births, 2017 deaths, High jumpers, American centenarians, American track and field athletes, German centenarians, German Jews, Jewish American sportspeople, Jewish centenarians, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Refugees from Nazism, Sportspeople from Baden-Württemberg, Sportspeople from New York City

Margaret "Gretel" Bergmann-Lambert (née Bergmann; 12 April 1914 – 25 July 2017) was a German-born American Jewish athlete. She was born in Laupheim, Württemberg. She competed as a high jumper during the 1930s. Because of her Jewish origins, the Nazis prevented her from taking part in the 1936 Summer Olympics, after which she left Germany and vowed never to return. She later moved to the United States.

Bergmann turned 100 in April 2014. 

Bergmann died in Queens, New York on 25 July 2017 at he age of 103.

[[Thomas Fleming]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2017 deaths, American novelists, American historians, Writers from New Jersey, People from Jersey City, New Jersey

Thomas James Fleming (July 5, 1927 – July 23, 2017) was an American military historian and historical novelist. He was born in Jersey City, New Jersey. 

Fleming was the author of over forty nonfiction and fiction titles. His work was about the particular interest on the American Revolution, with titles such as Liberty! The American Revolution And The Future Of America, Duel: Alexander Hamilton, Aaron Burr, and the History of America and Washington's Secret War: The Hidden History of Valley Forge.

Fleming died at his home in New York City on July 23, 2017 at the age of 90.

[[Solomon Perel]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, Living people, German Jews, Holocaust survivors, Jewish Israeli writers, Naturalized citizens of Israel, People from Lower Saxony

Solomon Perel (born 21 April 1925), also Shlomo Perel or Sally Perel, is a German-born Israeli author and motivational speaker. He was born in Peine, Lower Saxony, Germany to a German Jewish family. He escaped persecution by the Nazis by pretending to be an ethnic German.

His life story is told in the 1990 movie Europa Europa loosely based on his autobiography Ich war Hitlerjunge Salomon (I Was Hitler Youth Salomon).

[[It Just Comes Natural]]

CATEGORIES: 2006 albums, Country albums

It Just Comes Natural is the 24th studio album by George Strait. The album was released on October 3, 2006 through MCA Nashville Records. The song "Give It Away" from the album was Strait's 41st Number One for Billboard Hot Country Songs.

[[Sangul Utindaan]]

CATEGORIES: Ghana

A Sangul Utindaanː is a traditional spiritual custodian of the Sangul people in Northern Ghana. Some sources translate this position's name to mean the Sangul's "overlord" or "landlord". 

In November 2017, the serving Utindaan is Wunikpel Mbaliye Jato. The  descendants of the Utidaan are Gasetiib, a clan in the Tatale-Sangul District. This role is not the same as one with a similar name in the Saboba District of Northern Ghanabhggg, which has a different title and role.

[[List of governors of Bihar]]

CATEGORIES: Governors of Bihar, States and territories of India-related lists, Lists of governors, Lists of Indian people

The Governor of Bihar is a head and representative of the President of India in the state of Bihar. The Governor is appointed by the President for a time of 5 years. Phagu Chauhan is the current Governor of Bihar state.

[[Keshari Nath Tripathi]]

CATEGORIES: Politicians from Uttar Pradesh, Living people, 1934 births, Governors of Bihar, Governors of Meghalaya, Governors of Mizoram, Governors of West Bengal

Keshari Nath Tripathi (केसरी नाथ त्रिपाठी; born 10 November 1934) is an Indian politician. He was the Governor of West Bengal. He took promise as Governor of West Bengal on 24 July 2014 and as Governor of Bihar on 27 November in 2017.  He was selected as the Governor of Mizoram on 4 April 2015. He is an experienced BJP leader. Earlier, he was the speaker of Uttar Pradesh legislative assembly and the president of Uttar Pradesh unit of Bharatiya Janata Party.

[[Cheviot, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: 1810 establishments in Ohio, Ohio counties

Guernsey County is a county of Ohio in the United States. In 2010, 40,087 people lived there. The county seat is Cambridge.

[[Bad Waldsee]]

CATEGORIES: Spa towns in Germany

Bad Waldsee is a town in the district of Ravensburg in the state of Baden-Württemberg, Germany.

Bad Waldsee is 20 km south of Biberach an der Riß, and 20 km northeast of Ravensburg.

[[Formazza]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Piedmont

Formazza (Walliser German: Pomatt, Piedmontese: Formassa) is a comune (municipality) in the Province of Verbano-Cusio-Ossola in the Italian region Piedmont.

Formazza is about 160 northeast of Turin and 50 north of Verbania. It is on the border with Switzerland.

As of 2004 about 443 people lived there. It has an area of 131.8.

The municipality of Formazza contains the frazioni (subdivisions, mainly villages and hamlets) Foppiano, Antillone, Fondovalle, Chiesa, Valdo, San Michele, Ponte, Brendo, Grovella, Canza, Sotto Frua, La Frua, and Riale.

Formazza borders the following municipalities: Baceno, Bedretto (Switzerland), Bignasco (Switzerland), Binn (Switzerland), Bosco/Gurin (Switzerland), Cavergno (Switzerland), Premia, Reckingen-Gluringen (Switzerland), Ulrichen (Switzerland).

The village was founded by Walser and Walser German is still spoken.

Chesterfield is a major city in the East Midlands region of England. Other main cities in the East Midlands include: Nottingham, Leicester, Lincoln, Derby, Northampton, and Mansfield.

[[Circleville, Ohio]]

Circleville is a city in Ohio in the United States. It is the county seat of Pickaway County.

[[Logan County, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: Ohio counties, 1810s establishments in Ohio, 1818 establishments in the United States

Logan County is a county in the U.S. state of Ohio. In the 2010 census, 45,858 people lived there. The county seat is Bellefontaine. The county was founded in 1818 and named for Benjamin Logan, who fought Native Americans in the area.

[[Swedish Transport Agency's law-breaking of security for computer system]]

CATEGORIES: Sweden

Swedish Transport Agency's law-breaking of security for computer system was law-breaking - exposed by media in 2017 - regarding the security of  information in a database of the governmental agency, Swedish Transport Agency.

In January 2017 Sweden's Cabinet fired the agency's director, Maria Ågren; why she was fired was held secret for the public; instead, the public was told that she did not continue in the job, because of disagreement between Ågren and minister of infrastructure, Anna Johansson.

On 27 July 2017 the prime minister announced that two ministers will leave their job: Interior Minister Anders Ygeman and Infrastructure Minister Anna Johansson; this happened because " a no-confidence motion against three of the government's ministers by the opposition Alliance coalition".

[[Mary Ruwart]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, Living people, American political writers, American political activists, Writers from Detroit, Michigan, Politicians from Michigan, Writers from Texas, Politicians from Texas, 2008 United States presidential candidates, US Libertarian Party politicians

Mary J. Ruwart (born October 16, 1949) is a retired American biomedical researcher and libertarian speaker, writer, and activist.  She was a leading candidate for the 2008 Libertarian Party presidential nomination and is the author of the award-winning Healing Our World.

In March 2008, Ruwart announced her candidacy for the Libertarian presidential nomination in the 2008 election. She lost the nomination to Bob Barr on the sixth ballot at the 2008 Libertarian National Convention on May 25, 2008.

Ruwart unsuccessfully ran for Texas Comptroller in 2010 against incumbent Republican Susan Combs. She received 417,523 votes (10.5%) in a race that had no Democrat.

[[Leo Kinnunen]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Finnish racecar drivers, Formula One drivers

Leo Juhani "Leksa" Kinnunen (5 August 1943 – 26 July 2017) was a Finnish racing driver, and the first Formula One driver from Finland. He was born in Tampere, Finland.

Kinnunen won the Nordic Challenge Cup in 1969, the Interserie from 1971–1973, and helped Porsche to take the World Sportscar Championship for manufacturers in 1970 (drivers championships were not awarded until 1981). In 1974, he switched to Formula One. He was the last driver to compete in Formula One using an open-face helmet.

Kinnunen died on 26 July 2017 at his home in Turku, Finland of pneumonia at the age of 73.

[[Louise Merzeau]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Cancer deaths in France, French educators, French photographers, People from Paris

Sylvie Merzeau (commonly called Louise Merzeau, 8 November 1963 – 15 July 2017) was a French academic, university professor at the Paris Nanterre University, specializing on communication studies, as well as a photographer. She was a trustee of Wikimedia France. She was born in Paris.

Merzeau died in Paris on 15 July 2017 of pancreatic cancer at the age of 53.

[[Fritz Hellwig]]

CATEGORIES: 1912 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from cardiopulmonary arrest, European Commissioners, German centenarians, Nazis, Politicians from Saarland, Politicians of the Christian Democratic Union of Germany, Sturmabteilung people

Fritz Hellwig (3 August 1912 – 22 July 2017) was a German CDU politician and European Commissioner. 

He was born in Saarbrücken, Germany. Before and during the war he was a member of the Nazi Party and the SA. After the war he served as European Commissioner for Research, Technology and Information Distribution from 1967 through 1970. 

Hellwid turned 100 in August 2012. He died on 22 July 2017 in Berlin of cardiopulmonary arrest at the age of 104.

[[Giovanni Battista Pichierri]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2017 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Italy, Deaths from aortic aneurysm, Italian Roman Catholics, Roman Catholic archbishops

Giovanni Battista Pichierri (February 12, 1943 – July 26, 2017) was an Italian prelate of Roman Catholic Church. He was born in Sava, Apulia.

He was ordained to the priesthood in 1967. Pichierri served as bishop of the Diocese of Cerignola-Ascoli Satriano, Italy from 1990 to 1999. He then served as archbishop of the Archdiocese of Trani-Barletta-Bisceglie from 1999 to his death in 2017.

Pichierri died in Trani, Apulia of an aortic aneurysm on July 26, 2017 at the age of 74.

[[Lawrence Pezzulo]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from Alzheimer's disease, Disease-related deaths in Maryland, Ambassadors of the United States, Politicians from New York City, US Democratic Party politicians

Lawrence Anthony Pezzulo (May 3, 1926 – July 26, 2017) was an American politician and Foreign Service officer. He served as the United States Ambassador to Nicaragua (1979–1981) and to Uruguay (1977–1979) during the Jimmy Carter presidency. He was a member of the Democratic Party.

Pezzulo was born in New York City. He studied at Columbia University. He married Josephine DiMattia in February 1950. They had three children.

Pezzulo died on July 26, 2017 at his home in Baltimore, Maryland from complications of Alzheimer's disease at the age of 91.

[[Maxlei dos Santos Luzia]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from cerebral edema, Footballers from Rio de Janeiro, Brazilian association football goalkeepers

Maxlei dos Santos Luzia or simply Max (27 February 1975 – 26 July 2017) was a Brazilian goalkeeper. He was born in Rio de Janiero. He was known for playing for Portuguesa-RJ, Vila Nova and Botafogo.

In June 2017, Max was the victim of an attempted robbery. The former goalkeeper suffered a fractured right hand and a cerebral edema. On 26 July 2017, Santos Luzia died of a cerebral edema in Rio de Janeiro at the age of 42.

[[Michael McElhatton]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, Irish movie actors, Irish television actors, Irish voice actors, Irish stage actors, Actors from Dublin, Writers from Dublin

Michael McElhatton (born 12 September 1963) is an Irish actor and writer. He is best known for playing the role of Roose Bolton in the HBO series Game of Thrones. He joined the series as a guest star in the second season, and continued to play this role until season 5, promoted to a regular cast member.

His first well known role was that of Rats Doyle in the Irish sitcom Paths to Freedom.

In 2011, he had a role in the movie Albert Nobbs  directed by Rodrigo García, and the following year the short  Pentecost , which received a nomination for Best Short Film at the 2012 Academy Awards.

[[Chilika Lake]]

CATEGORIES: Lakes of India

Chilika Lake is the biggest brackish water lake on India's east coast. The lake is located in Odisha. It  is attached to the  Bay of Bengal. Part of the lake isa bird sanctuary.

[[Swedish Transport Agency]]

CATEGORIES: Government of Sweden, Transport in Sweden

The Swedish Transport Agency (Transportstyrelsen) is a Swedish government agency under the Ministry of Enterprise, Energy and Communications. It was formed on 1 January 2009, through a merger of several government agencies, including the Civil Aviation Administration.

It has its headquarters in Norrköping, Sweden.

The agency regulates and inspects transportation systems in Sweden.

Nakhon Ratchasima is a city in Thailand's Nakhon Ratchasima Province.

[[John Delaney]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, Businesspeople from New Jersey, Columbia University alumni, Politicians from New Jersey, 2020 United States presidential candidates, United States representatives from Maryland, US Democratic Party politicians

John Kevin "JK" Delaney (born April 16, 1963) is an American politician and businessman. He was the United States Representative for Maryland's 6th congressional district from 2013 to 2019.

On July 28, 2017, Delaney became the first Democrat to announce he is running for President in 2020. He ended his campaign in January 2020, days before the Iowa caucus.

[[Stephen Tobolowsky]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Jewish American actors, Jewish American musicians, Jewish American writers, Actors from Dallas, Texas, Writers from Texas, Musicians from Dallas, Texas

Stephen Harold Tobolowsky (born May 30, 1951) is an American actor, author, and musician. He is known for movie roles such as insurance agent Ned Ryerson in Groundhog Day and Sammy Jankis in Christopher Nolan's Memento, as well as such television characters as Commissioner Hugo Jarry (Deadwood), Bob Bishop (Heroes), Sandy Ryerson (Glee), Stu Beggs (Californication), and Action Jack Barker (Silicon Valley).

Tobolowsky is Jewish.

[[Michael Johnson (singer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2017 deaths, Disease-related deaths in Minnesota, American singer-songwriters, American pop singers, American pop musicians, American country guitarists, American country singers, American folk singers, American folk musicians, Singers from Colorado, Musicians from Colorado, Writers from Colorado

Michael Johnson (August 8, 1944 – July 25, 2017) was an American pop, country and folk singer-songwriter and guitarist. 

Johnson was best known for his 1978 hit song "Bluer Than Blue". He charted four hits on the Billboard Hot 100 charts, and nine more on the Hot Country Songs charts, including two Number One country hits in 1986's "Give Me Wings" and "The Moon Is Still Over Her Shoulder". He also co-wrote "Cain's Blood", the debut single of 1990s country group 4 Runner.

Johnson died in Minneapolis, Minnesota on July 25, 2017 after suffering from a long-illness at the age of 72.

[[Billy Joe Walker Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from renal failure, Disease-related deaths in Texas, American singer-songwriters, Writers from Texas, Singers from Texas, People from Midland, Texas

Billy Joe Walker Jr. (February 29, 1952 – July 25, 2017) was an American songwriter, record producer and recording artist. He made singles for Eddie Rabbitt, including "I Wanna Dance with You", "That's Why I Fell in Love with You" and "B-B-B-Burnin' Up with Love". He was born in Midland, Texas.

Walker Jr. produced the first three albums of Bryan White, and for Pam Tillis, Collin Raye and Travis Tritt. He was also a session musician who played guitar. Between 1987 and 1994, he recorded seven New Age albums, all for major labels.

Walker Jr. died following kidney failure on July 25, 2017 in Kerrville, Texas at the age of 64.

[[Joachim Vobbe]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2017 deaths, Bishops, Deaths from prostate cancer, Cancer deaths in Germany, German Roman Catholics, Old Catholics

Joachim Gerhard Vobbe (January 5, 1947 – July 26, 2017) was a German bishop for the Catholic Diocese of the Old Catholics in Germany. He was born in Bad Honnef, Germany.

Vobbe was ordained a priest on 14 June 1972. After serving as a chaplain (Kaplan) for five years in Catholic parishes in Cologne (1972–1974) and Düsseldorf (1974–1977), he joined the Old Catholic Church in 1977, becoming rector in Blumberg until 1982. He then served in Offenbach, latterly as Dean of Hesse.

Vobbe served as the Bishop of the Old Catholics in Germany (based in Bonn) until 2009. As bishop of a church in full communion with the Church of England, he has been licensed as an honorary assistant bishop in that church's Diocese in Europe since 1999.

Vobbe died at Königswinter on 26 July 2017 of prostate cancer at the age of 70.

[[Ramón Xirau]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from congestive heart failure, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Mexico, Spanish poets, Mexican poets, Mexican philosophers, Critics, Writers from Barcelona, Writers from Mexico City

Ramón Xirau Subías (raˈmon ʃiˈɾau, rəˈmoɲ ʃiˈɾaw) (20 January 1924 – 27 July 2017) was a Spanish-born Mexican poet, philosopher and literary critic. He was born in Barcelona, Spain.

Hampton Lansden Fancher (born July 18, 1938) is an American actor who became a movie producer and screenwriter in the late 1970s. He is known for writing the screenplay for Blade Runner.

[[Betty Boothroyd]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, Living people, Former Speakers of the House of Commons of the United Kingdom, Labour MPs (UK), People from Yorkshire

Betty Boothroyd, Baroness Boothroyd OM PC (born 8 October 1929) is a British politician. She served as a Labour Member of Parliament (MP) for West Bromwich and West Bromwich West from 1973 to 1992. 

From 1992 to 2000, she served as Speaker of the House of Commons. She was the first, and to date only, female Speaker of the House of Commons. She sits, by tradition, as a Crossbench peer in the House of Lords.
