[[Martin Shkreli]]

CATEGORIES: 1983 births, Living people, American fraudsters, Businesspeople from New York City

Martin Shkreli (ˈ, born March 17, 1983) is an American businessman, former hedge fund manager and convicted fraudster. He is the co-founder of the hedge funds Elea Capital, MSMB Capital Management, MSMB Healthcare, co-founder and former chief executive officer (CEO) of the biotechnology firm Retrophin, and founder and former CEO of Turing Pharmaceuticals.

[[Luis Fonsi]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, Living people, Puerto Rican singers, Guitarists, Songwriters, North American pianists, Puerto Rican actors

Luis Alfonso Rodríguez López-Cepero (born April 15, 1978), known by his stage name Luis Fonsi, is a Puerto Rican singer, songwriter and actor. He is best known for the hit song "Despacito" (2017). In January 2017, "Despacito" featuring Daddy Yankee was promoted and released. 

In 2011, Fonsi released the album Tierra Firme, and went on tour to promote it throughout Latin America.

On July 9, 2011, Billboard named Fonsi "Leader of Latin Music's New Generation".

On July 4, 2017, the music video has reached two billion views on YouTube, with the song becoming number one in nearly every Latin Billboard chart, and the most viewed video in the world. In August 2017, "Despacito" became the number one most viewed video on YouTube, with three billion views and counting.

As of 2018 he has broken six Guinness World Records and sold more than 11 million records with "Despacito".

After five years since "8", on 1 February 2019 his 10th studio album "Vida" was released. The track list contains "Despacito (Remix) ", "Échame la Culpa" and "Sola". The album topped the Billboard Top Latin Albums and Spanish album chart, and entered at number 18 of the Billboard 200.

In June 2018, Fonsi released the single "Calypso", with Stefflon Don. The song peaked at number 11 on the Hot Latin chart. On 2 November 2018, he collaborated on the track "Baby" by Clean Bandit from their second studio album. The song peaked at number 13 of Billboard Hot Dance/Electronic Songs and at number 15 of UK Singles Chart.

On 13 January 2019, the singer joined with Wisin, Alejandra Guzmán and Carlos Vives as coaches of the first Spanish season of La Voz by Telemundo.

[[Yèvre]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of France, Centre-Val de Loire

The Yèvre is a river in central France. It is a right tributary of the Cher river. It flows through the Cher department in the Centre-Val de Loire region.

[[Julia Michaels]]

CATEGORIES: Musicians from California, singers from California, Writers from California, Musicians from Iowa, Writers from Iowa, Singers from Iowa, American dancers, American pop singers, American pop musicians, American guitarists, American pianists, American singer-songwriters, people from Davenport, Iowa, 1993 births, living people

Julia Cavassos (better known as Julia Michaels; born November 13, 1993) is an American singer and songwriter. She is best known for her single "Issues". The song peaked at #11 on the United States Billboard Hot 100. It was marked double platinum by the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA).

Michaels' EP album, Nervous System, was released on July 28, 2017.

Her second single is "Uh Huh". This song was released on June 2, 2017.

Michaels said her inspirations were Fiona Apple, Laura Marling and Paramore.

Michaels was born in Davenport, Iowa. She later moved to Santa Clarita, California, a suburb of Los Angeles.

[[Subsidiary]]

CATEGORIES: Business

A subsidiary is a company that is controlled by its parent company. Even though a subsidiary works on its own, and its purposes are different from that of its parent company, the parent company is in control of its subsidiary.

A company's subsidiary is different from a company's division because a division works together with its parent company. A division's goal is usually similar to that of its parent company, and the division has to use its parent company's name. A subsidiary can use a name different from that of its parent company.

For example, YouTube is a subsidiary of Google, because Google is a search engine, while YouTube is a video sharing website. Google Videos is a division of Google, because Google Videos is a search engine that searches videos on the Internet. This is to match its parent company Google as a search engine. Also, YouTube has an entirely different name and logo from Google's, while Google Videos, as a division, must use Google's name and logo.

[[España Boulevard]]

CATEGORIES: Streets in Metro Manila

España Boulevard is an important road in Manila, the capital of the Philippines, that has 8 lanes (4 in each direction). It starts at a roundabout or traffic circle at the boundary of Quezon City and Manila and ends at a Y-shaped intersection with Lerma and Nicanor B. Reyes Streets in Manila. It is named after the Spanish name of Spain, the Philippines' colonial power for 333 years.

[[List of roads in Metro Manila]]

CATEGORIES: Roads in the Philippines, Metro Manila

This is an alpabetical list of important roads that are located in Metro Manila, the capital region of the Philippines. It also includes roads that have parts not located in the region, like neighboring provinces.

Roads in Metro Manila are usually classified into highways, avenues, and streets.

[[Jerome Adams]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Living people, American physicians, Surgeon Generals of the United States, Scientists from New Jersey, People from Orange, New Jersey

Jerome Michael Adams (born September 22, 1974) is an American anesthesiologist. He was the 20th Surgeon General of the United States from September 2017 to January 2021.

Before assuming his current role, he served as the Indiana State Health Commissioner from 2014 to 2017. On June 29, 2017, President Donald Trump nominated Adams to become Surgeon General of the United States. Adams was confirmed by the United States Senate on August 3, 2017.

[[Erling Brøndum]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2017 deaths, Danish politicians, Danish writers, Danish journalists

Erling Brøndum (11 July 1930 – 4 August 2017) was a Danish journalist and politician. He began at Bornholms Tidende as a reporter, and at age 26, was named chief editor. 

After fourteen years as the publication's editor, Brøndum joined the staff of the Horsens Folkeblad. In 1973, Poul Hartling named Brøndum Minister of Defence. He left the post in 1975, and returned to Horsens Folkeblad and the Aalborg Stiftstidende.

Brøndum died in Copenhagen, Denmark on 4 August 2017 at the age of 87.

[[Clayton Williams]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2020 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Disease-related deaths in Texas, American philanthropists, Politicians from Texas, Businesspeople from Texas, People from Midland, Texas, US Republican Party politicians

Clayton Wheat "Claytie" Williams Jr. (October 8, 1931 – February 14, 2020) was an American businessman and philanthropist.

Williams ran for state governor in 1990. Despite securing the Republican nomination and initially leading in the polls against Democratic challenger State Treasurer Ann Richards by twenty points, Williams ultimately lost the race.

[[William P. Hobby Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, Living people, Lieutenant Governors of Texas, Politicians from Houston, Texas, US Democratic Party politicians

William Pettus “Bill” Hobby Jr. (born January 19, 1932) is an American Democratic politician who served a record eighteen years as the 37th Lieutenant Governor. 

Hobby Jr. held that office from January 16, 1973 to January 15, 1991 for five unprecedented terms, he was the last lieutenant governor to serve a two-year term and the first elected to a four-year term when the Texas Constitution was amended to lengthen terms for statewide elected officeholders to four years beginning with the 1974 elections. The principal duty of the Texas lieutenant governor is to preside over the Texas State Senate.

[[Amorsolo Street]]

CATEGORIES: Streets in Metro Manila

Amorsolo Street is a street located in the western part of Makati, the Philippines. It is located next to Chino Roces Avenue in the west. It is named after the famous Filipino painter and national artist Fernando Amorsolo.

[[Hollywood Steps Out]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 movies, Looney Tunes, English-language movies

Hollywood Steps Out is a 1941 short Merrie Melodies cartoon by Warner Bros., directed by Tex Avery. The cartoon features caricatures by Ben Shenkman of Hollywood celebrities from the 1930s and early 1940s, including Cary Grant, Clark Gable, Wallace Beery, Bing Crosby, Greta Garbo, and Groucho Marx.

[[Escolta Street]]

CATEGORIES: Streets in Metro Manila

Escolta Street is historic west to east street in the downtown district of Binondo in Manila, the capital of the Philippines. It is very near to (and parallel to) Pasig River. It starts at Plaza Moraga to the west and ends at Plaza Santa Cruz and Quintin Paredes Street to the east. It contains some examples of early skyscraper design in the country.

The name of the street was derived from the Spanish word "escoltar", meaning "to escort" or "to accompany". It is known as calle de la Escolta in the Spanish language. It was built in 1594 and was the center of business and commerce in Metro Manila until the 1960s, when the center of business slowly moved to Makati.

[[Primary sector of the economy]]

CATEGORIES: Economics

The primary sector of the economy of a country is the first division of the economic sector. It includes agriculture, farming, mining, and fishing.

[[National Changhua University of Education]]

CATEGORIES: Colleges and universities in Taiwan, 1745 establishments, Establishments in Taiwan

National Changhua University of Education (NCUE; 國立彰化師範大學) is a national research university located in Taiwan.The main campus is in Changhua County.It was founded in 1745.

The Paysandú department (Departamento de Paysandú) is a department of Uruguay. The capital is the city of Paysandú.

Its ISO 3166-2 code  is UY-PA.

[[Payyanur]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Kerala

Payyanur is a town and municipality in Kannur district in the state of Kerala in India. This municipality is formed by three administrative villages: Vellur, Korom and Payyanur. Other villages are: Annur and Kokkanissery. The town is on the banks of the Perumba River.

[[Kingdom of Kent]]

CATEGORIES: Kent

The Kingdom of Kent was a kingdom of the Jutes in southeast England.

[[Always Be My Baby]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 songs, 1996 songs, Mariah Carey songs, Pop songs, R&B songs

"Always Be My Baby" is a song by American singer and songwriter  Mariah Carey from her fifth studio album Daydream (1995). It was released by Columbia Records in March 9, 1996 as the third US single and fourth overall. The song was written by Carey, Jermaine Dupri and Manuel Seal. A mid-tempo song, "Always Be My Baby" became Carey's eleventh number one single on the Billboard 100.

[[Ana-Maria Avram]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2017 deaths, Romanian composers, People from Bucharest

Ana-Maria Avram (12 September 1961 – 1 August 2017) was a Romanian composer. Her works deal with the spectral music style. She represents with Iancu Dumitrescu the Hyper-Spectral trend in contemporary avant-garde music, conductor with Dumitrescu of the Hyperion Ensemble. She has composed around 90 works as of 2009: music for soloists, chamber music, music for orchestra, electronic music and computer-assisted music. She was born in Bucharest.

Avram died on 1 August 2017 at the age of 55.

[[Nicole Bricq]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2017 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls, Socialist Party (France) politicians

Nicole Bricq (ni.kɔl bʁik; 10 June 1947 – 6 August 2017) was a French politician. She was a member of the Senate of France, representing the Seine-et-Marne department. Bricq was a member of the Socialist Party. On 16 May 2012 she was appointed Minister of Ecology, Energy, and Sustainable Development in the government of Jean-Marc Ayrault.

Bricq was born in La Rochefoucauld, Charente. She studied at Montesquieu University.

On 6 August 2017, Bricq died from complications of a fall in Paris at the age of 70.

[[Martin Roth (museum director)]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2017 deaths, People from Stuttgart

Martin Roth (16 January 1955 – 6 August 2017) was a German museum director. He was Director General of the Dresden State Art Collections from 2001 to 2011 and Director of the Victoria and Albert Museum in London, England, from 2011 to 2016. He was born in Stuttgart, Germany.

Roth died in Berlin on 6 August 2017 at the age of 62.

[[Pushpa Mittra Bhargava]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2017 deaths, Indian scientists, Indian writers

Pushpa Mittra Bhargava (22 February 1928 – 1 August 2017) was an Indian scientist, writer, and administrator. He founded the Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology, a federally funded research institute, in Hyderabad. He was outspoken and highly influential in the development of scientific temper in India, and argued that scientific rationalism needed to be cultivated as a civic duty.

Bhargava died on 1 August 2017, aged 89 at Hyderabad, India.

[[Santosh Mohan Dev]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from stomach cancer, Cancer deaths in India, Indian politicians

Santosh Mohan Dev (সন্তোষ মোহন দেব) (1 April 1934 – 2 August 2017), was a Indian political leader and a key member of the Indian National Congress. Dev was first elected to the Parliament in 1980, the first of his seven terms in office as the Member Of Parliament. Out of these seven, he has represented Silchar, Assam five times and he was elected from Tripura twice. He was born in Silchar, Assam Province, British India.

Dev died of stomach cancer on 2 August 2017 in Silchar at the age of 83.

[[Carmen de Lavallade]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, American movie actors, American stage actors, American dancers, Actors from Los Angeles, California

Carmen de Lavallade (born March 6, 1931) is an American actress, dancer and choreographer. She was born in Los Angeles, California. She was married to Geoffrey Holder from 1955 until his death in 2014. 

She made her television debut in John Butler's ballet Flight, and in 1957 she appeared in the television production of Duke Ellington's A Drum Is a Woman. She appeared in several off-Broadway productions, including Othello and Death of a Salesman.

[[K. Alex Müller]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, Living people, Swiss scientists, Physicists, Swiss educators

PhysicsKarl Alexander Müller (born April 20, 1927) is a Swiss physicist. He received the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1987 with Georg Bednorz for their work in superconductivity in ceramic materials. They reported their discovery in the June 1986 issue of Zeitschrift für Physik B.

Müller joined the Battelle Memorial Institute in Geneva, soon becoming the manager of a magnetic resonance group. During this time he became a lecturer at the University of Zürich. 

[[Hinrich Lehmann-Grube]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2017 deaths, Cancer deaths in Germany, German mayors, Leipzig, People from former German territories, People from Kaliningrad, Politicians of the Social Democratic Party of Germany

Hinrich Lehmann-Grube (21 December 1932 – 6 August 2017) was a German politician. He served as Mayor of Leipzig from 1990 through 1998. He was a member of the Social Democratic Party of Germany. He was born in Königsberg (present day Kaliningrad, Russia).

Lehmann-Grube died in Leipzig of cancer on 6 August 2017 at the age of 84.

[[Love Takes Time]]

CATEGORIES: 1990 songs, Mariah Carey songs, Pop songs, Soul songs, R&B songs

"Love Takes Time" is a song recorded by American singer-songwriter Mariah Carey. It was written by Carey and Ben Margulies, and was produced by Walter Afanasieff for Carey's debut album, Mariah Carey (1990). It was released as the album's second single on July 9, 1990 through CBS Records. "Love Takes Time" became Carey's second Billboard Hot 100 number-one single.

[[Alexander Strider]]

CATEGORIES: Buses

The Alexander Strider is a single-decker step-entrance bus body built by Walter Alexander Coachbuilders from 1993 to 1997. It could be built on the Dennis Lance, Volvo B10B, Volvo B10M or Scania L113 chassis.

[[Designated survivor]]

CATEGORIES: Executive branch of the United States government

The designated survivor (also called designated successor) is a member of the US president's cabinet who goes to a remote, secure location at a time when all the government leadership is gathered in one place, such as during the State of the Union speech or a presidential inauguration. This is to make sure that the government will continue in case of some catastrophe that would result in harm to the President and many top elected officials at once.

The recent designated survivor is Sonny Perdue, President Donald Trump's Secretary of Agriculture, for the 2018 State of the Union Address.

[[Alexander PS type]]

CATEGORIES: Buses

The Alexander PS was a step-entrance single-decker bus body built by Walter Alexander Coachbuilders from 1980s to 1990s. It could be built on the Dennis Lance, Leyland Lynx, Mercedes-Benz O405, Scania N113, Volvo B10M or Iveco Turbocity chassis.

[[Río Negro Department]]

CATEGORIES: Departments of Uruguay, 1880 establishments, 19th-century establishments in Uruguay

The Río Negro department (Departamento de Río Negro) is a department of Uruguay. The capital is the city of Fray Bentos.

Its ISO 3166-2 code  is UY-RN.

[[Mycoplasma amphoriforme]]

CATEGORIES: Diseases caused by bacteria

Mycoplasma amphoriforme is a type of bacteria. It belongs in a larger group Mycoplasma. This group of bacteria do not have a cell like other bacteria. Because this bacteria does not have a cell wall medicines may not cure an infection with this bacteria. Penicillin  and other medications cannot cure this infection. There are other medications that will work. This group of bacteria are the  smallest ones discovered. These bacteria do not need oxygen.

This bacterium has been found in people who are sick. Some people who have lung infections and can not fight illnesses have an infection with this bacterium. It moves by gliding and has a pointed tip that looks the same as M. gallepticum, and M. pneumonia. If a person has an infection with this bacterium they might breathe fast and their hearts could beat fast.

[[Latching on (breastfeeding)]]

CATEGORIES: Breasts, Women, Babies

Latching on is how the the baby fastens to the breast while breastfeeding. A good latch helps the baby get milk. This happens when the bottom of the areola (the area around the nipple) is in the baby's mouth. When the nipple is far back inside the baby's mouth this is a good latch. A latch that is not good happens when the baby does not have enough of the breast in his/her mouth. A shallow or short latch causes the nipple skin to press against the hard bones in the top of the baby's mouth. That will cause cracked nipples on the mother. Cracked nipples are painful and can bleed.

[[De minimis]]

CATEGORIES: Law

De minimis is a legal term that means that small things do not matter in the law. The term is short for the Latin maxim (saying) de minimis non curat lex.

[[Betty Cuthbert]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from multiple sclerosis, Disease-related deaths in Australia, Australian athletes, Sportspeople from New South Wales, People with multiple sclerosis

Elizabeth "Betty" Cuthbert AM, MBE (20 April 1938 – 7 August 2017) was an Australian athlete and a fourfold Olympic champion. She was born in Merrylands, New South Wales.

During her career, she set world records for 60 metres, 100 yards, 200 metres, 220 yards and 440 yards. She went to Ermington Public School which inspired and supported her to go in to the Olympics.August 2017 Cuthbert also contributed to Australian relay teams completing a win in the 4 × 100 metres, 4 × 110 yards, 4 × 200 metres and 4 × 220 yards. Cuthbert had a distinctive running style, with a high knee lift and mouth wide open.

Cuthbert died of complications from multiple sclerosis at her home in Mandurah, Western Australia on 7 August 2017 at the age of 79.

[[Darren Daulton]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from brain cancer, Cancer deaths in Florida, Philadelphia Phillies players, Florida Marlins players, Sportspeople from Kansas, Writers from Kansas

Darren Arthur Daulton (January 3, 1962 – August 6, 2017), nicknamed Dutch, was an American professional baseball player who played catcher in Major League Baseball (MLB). He was a three-time MLB All-Star with the Philadelphia Phillies, and won a World Series with the Florida Marlins in 1997.

Daulton died from brain cancer on August 6, 2017 in Clearwater, Florida at the age of 55.

[[Ernst Zündel]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2017 deaths, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Germany, Deaths from myocardial infarction, German writers, Holocaust deniers, Neo-Nazis, People from Baden-Württemberg

Ernst Christof Friedrich Zündel (April 24, 1939 —August 5, 2017) was a German publisher and pamphleteer known for promoting Holocaust denial. He had been jailed several times: in Canada for publishing literature "likely to incite hatred against an identifiable group", and on charges of being a threat to national security; in the United States, for overstaying his visa; and in Germany for charges of "inciting racial hatred".

Zündel died at his home in Germany, of a suspected heart attack, on August 5, 2017.

[[Cracked nipples]]

CATEGORIES: Breasts

Cracked nipples can happen when a mother breastfeeds her infant and it can be very painful. This happens for many reasons. The nipples can hurt, dry, or bleed. When the baby is breastfeeding, the cracked nipple can cause great pain. Many times this severe pain will make the mother stop breastfeeding. The crack looks like a cut across the tip of the nipple. Cracked nipples can be treated and healed.

[[Don Baylor]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from multiple myeloma, Cancer deaths in Texas, Baltimore Orioles players, Oakland Athletics players, Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim players, New York Yankees players, Boston Red Sox players, Minnesota Twins players, Colorado Rockies, Chicago Cubs managers, African-American baseball players, Sportspeople from Austin, Texas

Donald Edward Baylor (June 28, 1949 – August 7, 2017) was an American professional baseball player and manager. During his 19 seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB), Baylor was a power hitter known for crowding the plate, and was a first baseman, left fielder, and designated hitter.

Baylor played for six different American League (AL) teams, primarily the Baltimore Orioles and California Angels, but also played for the Oakland Athletics, New York Yankees, Minnesota Twins, and Boston Red Sox. In 1979, Baylor was an All-Star and won the AL Most Valuable Player Award.

Baylor won three Silver Slugger Awards, the Roberto Clemente Award, and was a member of the 1987 World Series champions.

After his playing career, Baylor managed the expansion Colorado Rockies for six years and the Chicago Cubs for three seasons. He was named NL Manager of the Year in 1995 and inducted into the Angels Hall of Fame.

Baylor died on August 7, 2017, at the age of 68 from multiple myeloma in Austin, Texas.

[[Haruo Nakajima]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Japanese movie actors

Haruo Nakajima (January 1, 1929 – August 7, 2017) was a Japanese actor. He was born in Yamagata. Nakajima was best known for portraying Godzilla from the 1950s through the early 1970s. Nakajima was Godzilla for 12 movies straight. He retired from acting in 1973.

Nakajima died on August 7, 2017 in Tokyo of pneumonia at the age of 88.

[[Bobby Morgan (baseball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, Living people, Brooklyn Dodgers players, Philadelphia Phillies players, St. Louis Cardinals players, Chicago Cubs players, Sportspeople from Oklahoma City

Bobby Morris Morgan (born June 29, 1926) is an American former professional baseball infielder. He played eight seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB) between 1950 and 1958 for the Brooklyn Dodgers, Philadelphia Phillies, St. Louis Cardinals, and Chicago Cubs. He retired in 1958.

Morgan was born in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.

[[Julius W. Becton Jr.]]

CATEGORIES: Purple Heart recipients, 1926 births, Living people, American military people, American educators, People from Bryn Mawr, Pennsylvania, Writers from Pennsylvania

Julius Wesley Becton Jr. (born June 29, 1926) is an American military official. He is a retired United States Army lieutenant general. He served as Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) during the Ronald Reagan and George H. W. Bush presidencies from 1985 to 1989. He is also a education administrator. 

Becton went on to serve in the Korean War and the Vietnam War, eventually rising to the rank of lieutenant general in 1978 and command of VII Corps in Europe during the Cold War. Becton retired from the U.S. Army in 1983, after nearly 40 years of service.

His autobiography, Becton: Autobiography of a Soldier and Public Servant, was published in 2008 by Naval Institute Press. 

[[Gary Cohn]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Living people, Politicians from Cleveland, Ohio, Directors of the National Economic Council, Businesspeople from Cleveland, Ohio, US Democratic Party politicians

Gary David Cohn (born August 27, 1960) is an American investment banker and political figure. He is the chief economic advisor to President Donald Trump and Director of the National Economic Council. He was formerly the president and chief operating officer of Goldman Sachs from 2006 to 2017. Cohn is a registered Democrat, but has donated extensively to Republican politicians as well.

Cohn was thought to be one of the most influential voices in the Trump administration. On March 6, 2018, it was reported that Cohn planned to resign from his position in the coming weeks.

[[Carl Panzram]]

CATEGORIES: 1891 births, 1930 deaths, American serial killers, Executed American serial killers, People executed by hanging, People from Minnesota

Carl Panzram (June 28, 1891 - September 5, 1930) was an American serial killer who was hanged for murder. He served time under his own name and various aliases in Fresno, California; Rusk, Texas; The Dalles, Oregon; Harrison, Idaho; Butte, Montana; Montana State Reform School in Miles City; Montana State Prison (as "Jeff Davis" #4194 #3194 and "Jefferson Rhodes" #4396); Oregon State Prison ("Jefferson Baldwin" #7390); Bridgeport, Connecticut ("John O'Leary"); Sing Sing Correctional Facility, New York ("John O'Leary" #75182); Clinton Correctional Facility, New York ("John O'Leary" #75182); and Washington, D.C (Carl Panzram #33379) and Leavenworth, Kansas (Carl Panzram #31614). While incarcerated, Panzram frequently attacked guards and refused to follow their orders. The guards retaliated, subjecting him to beatings and other punishments.

[[Yoshio Tsuchiya]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, Living people, Japanese movie actors, Japanese writers

Yoshio Tsuchiya is a Japanese actor. He appeared in such movies as Toshio Matsumoto's surreal Bara No Soretsu (a.k.a. Funeral Parade of Roses) and Akira Kurosawa's Seven Samurai (as the firebrand farmer Rikichi) and Red Beard, and Kihachi Okamoto's Kill!.  

He has a long-standing interest in UFOs and had written several books on the subject. He preferred starring in science fiction movies, usually as aliens, or people possessed by them, in such movies as Battle in Outer Space, Monster Zero, and Destroy All Monsters. 

[[Katsumi Tezuka]]

CATEGORIES: 1912 births, Living people, Japanese movie actors, Japanese centenarians

Katsumi Tezuka (born August 31, 1912) is a Japanese actor. He is best known for playing monsters in several Toho science fiction and horror movies directed by Ishirō Honda. He played Godzilla, alongside Haruo Nakajima, in the 1954 movie Godzilla.

[[Akira Takarada]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, Living people, Japanese movie actors, Japanese television actors

Akira Takarada is a Japanese movie actor. He is most known in the west for his roles in the Godzilla movie series. He appeared in the 2014 American reboot of the franchise. He also appeared in Half Human (1955), The Last War (1961), Frankenstein Conquers the World (1965), King Kong Escapes (1967), and Latitude Zero (1969).

[[Yukiko Shimazaki]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, Actors from Tokyo

Yukiko Shimazaki is a Japanese actress and singer. She appeared in more than twenty movies from 1950 to 1964. She was married to director Tatsumi Kumashiro from 1955 to 1967. Her best known roles were in Repast (1951) and in Seven Samurai (1954).

[[Río Negro (Uruguay)]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of Uruguay, Rivers of Brazil

The Río Negro (Black River) is the most important river in Uruguay.is a river in central France. It is a left tributary of the Uruguay river. It starts in southern Brazil and flows west across the entire width of Uruguay to the Uruguay River.

The course of the Río Negro across Uruguay effectively divides the south of the country from the north.

[[Sigmund Sobolewski]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, People with Alzheimer's disease, Activists, Polish educators, Holocaust survivors

Sigmund Sobolewski (ˈɕiɡmunt sɔbɔˈlɛfskʲi) (May 11, 1923 – August 7, 2017) was a Polish activist, lecturer and Holocaust survivor. He was the 88th prisoner to enter Auschwitz on the very first transport to the concentration camp on June 14, 1940. He remained a prisoner for four and a half years during World War II. He was a critic of Holocaust denial and was known for having confronted modern neo-Nazis, anti-Semites and Holocaust deniers. 

[[Kyōko Kagawa]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, Actors from Tokyo

Kyōko Kagawa is a Japanese actress. She is known for her roles in movies like Tokyo Story, Sansho the Bailiff and High and Low. She has appeared in 118 movies. Her most recent movie was Ballad in 2009.

In late 2011, the National Museum of Modern Art, Tokyo, honored her long career and her contribution to Japanese cinema with an exhibition titled 'Kyoko Kagawa, Film Actress'.

[[La Plata, Maryland]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Maryland, County seats in Maryland

La Plata is a city in Charles County, Maryland, United States. In 2010, 8,753 people lived there. It is the county seat of Charles County and home of the Charles County Courthouse.

La Plata was hit by two tornadoes, one in November 1926 that killed 13 people at La Plata Elementary School, and another in April 2002.

[[Annie Cordy]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2020 deaths, Belgian movie actors, Belgian singers, Comedians, Dancers, Deaths from cardiac arrest

Baroness Léonie Cooreman, known under the stage name Annie Cordy (16 June 1928 – 4 September 2020) was a Belgian movie actress and singer. She appeared in 50 movies beginning in 1954. 

She staged many memorable appearances at Bruno Coquatrix' famous Paris Olympia. Her version of "La Ballade de Davy Crockett" was number 1 in the charts for five weeks in France in August 1956.

Cordy died on 4 September 2020 from cardiac arrest in Vallauris, France, aged 92.

[[Amir Fryszer Guttman]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths by drowning, Israeli singers, LGBT singers, People from Haifa

Amir Fryszer Guttman (April 25, 1976 – July 23, 2017) was an Israeli singer, musician, choreographer, actor, and theater director. He died from drowning after being swept away with his niece, whom he had held above water; his niece survived.

[[Jerry Tarbot]]

CATEGORIES: 1882 births, 1972 deaths

Jerry Tarbot was an American conman who claimed he was an amnesia victim of World War I. On April 10, 1926 The Healdsburg Tribune published on article/photograph on Tarbot calling him the "sliding ghost" of World War I.

[[Princess Superstar]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, American Jews, American rap musicians from New York, Hip hop musicians, Electronic musicians, Living people

Concetta Kirschner (born February 25, 1971), better known as Princess Superstar, is an American rapper and DJ. She is best known for her hit songs "Baby Babysitter" (2001) and "Perfect" (2005).

She calls her music "flip-flop" which is a mixture of hip hop and electronica. In summer 2014 she had her reality television show "I Love Princess Superstar" on her YouTube account.

[[USS Robalo]]

CATEGORIES: Naval ships of the United States

The USS Robalo (SS-273)  was a Gato class submarine of the US Navy in World War II. The submarine went on three patrols.

[[West Creek Township, Lake County, Indiana]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Indiana

West Creek Township is one of eleven townships in Lake County, Indiana. When counted at 2010, its population was 6,826 people and it had 2,664 houses.

[[National Super Alliance]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 establishments, Politics of Africa, Establishments in Africa

The National Super Alliance, known by the abbreviation NASA, is a Kenyan political coalition that was formed in January 2017 by opposition parties. These parties include the Orange Democratic Movement (ODM), Wiper Democratic Movement (Wiper), Forum for the Restoration of Democracy - Kenya (FORD-Kenya), Amani National Congress (ANC), National Rainbow Coalition, Progressive Party of Kenya, CCU, Muungano and other parties.

In the 2017 General Elections the flagbearer of the coalition will be Raila Amollo Odinga and his running mate Kalonzo Musyoka. They'll be seeking to oust incumbent president Uhuru Kenyatta.

[[Nankai University]]

CATEGORIES: Colleges and universities in the People's Republic of China, 1919 establishments in Asia, 20th century establishments in China

Nankai University or NKU (simplified Chinese: 南开大学; traditional Chinese: 南開大學;), is a famous university in Tianjin, China. It was founded by Yan Xiu and Zhang Boling in 1919. The first Premier of the People's Republic of China Zhou Enlai graduated from Nankai University.

[[Arrondissements of the Loir-et-Cher department]]

CATEGORIES: Arrondissements of France

There are 3 arrondissements in the Loir-et-Cher department. The French departments, and in other countries, are divided into arrondissements, which may be translated into English as districts (in some cases, as boroughs). The capital of an arrondissement is called a subprefecture.

If the prefecture (capital) of the department is in an arrondissement, that prefecture is the capital of the arrondissement, acting both as a prefecture and as a subprefecture.

Arrondissements are further divided into communes.

The arrondissements of Loir-et-Cher are:

[[Fläsch]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities of Graubünden

Fläsch is a municipality of the district Landquart in the canton of Graubünden in Switzerland.

[[Kuzakai Station]]

CATEGORIES: Iwate Prefecture, Railway stations in Iwate Prefecture

Kuzakai Station is a train station in Miyako, Iwate Prefecture, Japan.

[[Dobra, Bolesławiec County]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Poland

Dobra is a village in the administrative district of Gmina Bolesławiec in Bolesławiec County, Lower Silesian Voivodeship in southwestern Poland. It is approximately 4 west of Bolesławiec, and 108 west of the regional capital Wrocław.

[[Geishouse]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Haut-Rhin

Geishouse is a commune in the Haut-Rhin department of east France.

[[Dejan Miladinović]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2017 deaths, People from Belgrade

Dejan Miladinović, (Дејан Миладиновић; 2 December 1948 – 3 August 2017) was a Serbian opera director. He was born in Belgrade, former Yugoslavia. Miladinović has served as Principal Stage Director and two times as Artistic Director of the National Opera of Novi Sad. He has also served as Director and Artistic Councilor for "Grand Opera Projects" with Convention Centre "Sava" in Belgrade.

Miladinović died in Belgrade on 3 August 2017 at the age of 68.

[[Patsy Ticer]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2017 deaths, Accidental deaths from falls in the United States, American mayors, Politicians from Virginia, US Democratic Party politicians, People from Alexandria, Virginia

Patricia Smith "Patsy" Ticer (January 6, 1935 – August 7, 2017) was an American politician. She was born in Alexandria, Virginia. She was a member of the Democratic Party. Ticer served on the City Council of Alexandria, Virginia in the 1980s. She then served as Mayor of Alexandria from 1991 to 1996. Ticer served in the Senate of Virginia from 1996 until her retirement in 2011.

Ticer died in a hospital in Alexandria, Virginia from complications from a fall on August 7, 2017 at the age of 82.

[[Gonzague Saint Bris]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2017 deaths, Road accident deaths, French novelists, French journalists

Gonzague Saint Bris (16 January 1948 – 8 August 2017) was a French award-winning novelist, biographer and journalist. He won the 2002 Prix Interallié for Les Vieillards de Brighton. He was the founder of La Forêt des livres, an annual book festival, and the Cabourg Film Festival. He was born in Loches, Indre-et-Loire.

Saint Bris was killed in a car crash on 8 August 2017 in Saint-Hymer, Calvados at the age of 69.

[[Cluster analysis]]

CATEGORIES: Statistics

Clustering or cluster analysis is a type of data analysis. The analyst groups objects so that objects in the same group (called a cluster) are more similar to each other than to objects in other groups (clusters) in some way. This is a common task in data mining.

[[Dick MacPherson]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2017 deaths, American football coaches, Sportspeople from Maine

Richard Francis "Dick" MacPherson (November 4, 1930 – August 8, 2017) was an American football coach. 

He was born in Old Town, Maine. He served as the head coach at the University of Massachusetts Amherst from 1971 to 1977 and at Syracuse University from 1981 to 1990. 

[[Mercedes-Benz TN]]

CATEGORIES: Buses, Vans, Mercedes-Benz automobiles

The Mercedes-Benz TN (Transporter Ne, Internally called T1) were vans and minibuses built by Mercedes-Benz from 1977 to 1995. it was available as a box van, a flat bed light truck or a minibus.

[[Arrondissement of Blois]]

CATEGORIES: Arrondissements of France

The arrondissement of Blois is an arrondissement of France, in the Loir-et-Cher department of the Centre-Val de Loire region. Its capital is the city of Blois.

[[Annie Up]]

CATEGORIES: 2013 albums

Annie Up is the second studio album by Pistol Annies. The album was released on May 7, 2013 through RCA Records Nashville.

[[Arrondissement of Vendôme]]

CATEGORIES: Arrondissements of France

The arrondissement of Vendôme is an arrondissement of France, in the Loir-et-Cher department of the Centre-Val de Loire region. Its capital is the city of Vendôme.

[[Eugenio Martínez]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2021 deaths, American criminals, Businesspeople from Miami, Florida

Eugenio Rolando Martínez (alias Musculito, July 8, 1922 – January 30, 2021) was an American real estate agent who was a member of the anti-Castro movement in the early 1960s, and later was one of the five men recruited by G. Gordon Liddy and E. Howard Hunt in 1972 for the Memorial Day weekend Watergate burglary at the Democratic National Committee (DNC) headquarters in Washington, D.C. After completing his prison term, Martinez was pardoned by President Ronald Reagan in 1983.

Martínez died on January 30, 2021 in Minneola, Florida at the age of 98.

[[Alexander Butterfield]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, Living people, American military people, Businesspeople from Florida, Politicians from Florida, People from Pensacola, Florida

Alexander Porter Butterfield (born April 6, 1926) is a U.S. military officer, public servant, and businessman. He served as the deputy assistant to President Richard Nixon from 1969 to 1973.

Butterfield revealed the existence of the White House taping system on July 13, 1973, during the Watergate scandal investigation, but had no involvement in the scandal. From 1973 to 1975, he served as administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration.

[[Arrondissement of Romorantin-Lanthenay]]

CATEGORIES: Arrondissements of France

The arrondissement of Romorantin-Lanthenay is an arrondissement of France, in the Loir-et-Cher department of the Centre-Val de Loire region. Its capital is the city of Romorantin-Lanthenay.

[[Shahid Khaqan Abbasi]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Pakistan

Shahid Khaqan Abbasi (Urdu/شاہد خاقان عباسی; born 27 December 1958) is a Pakistani politician who was the Prime Minister of Pakistan, from August 1, 2017 to May 31, 2018. He is a member of the ruling Pakistan Muslim League (N) (PML-N).

Abbasi served as the Minister for Petroleum and Natural Resources in the third Sharif ministry from 2013 to 2017, and briefly held the cabinet portfolio of Minister for Commerce in the Gillani ministry in 2008.

On 1 August 2017, Abbasi was elected Prime Minister of Pakistan after the resignation of outgoing Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif after Panama Papers case decision.

[[United States Army trucks]]

In 1915, the US Army started testing trucks that were made to go off-road to see if they could replace horses and mules.  Since then, the Army has built many different kinds of trucks or had private companies build trucks for them.

[[Operation Sentinelle]]

CATEGORIES: National security, Military of France

Operation Sentinelle is a counter-terrorism mission of the French army. It was put in place in January 2015 after the attacks against the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo and the supermarket Hyper Casher.

It was the President of the French Republic, François Hollande, who took the decision to create it and his successor Emmanuel Macron extended it.

All the units of the French army but also of the French Air Force and the French Navy participate in Operation Sentinelle. It results in a massive presence of French soldiers in the streets, public places and public transport, in reinforcement of the police and the gendarmerie.

Their function is to provide surveillance and dissemination of jihadist threats.

[[Grumman S-2 Tracker]]

CATEGORIES: United States Navy aircraft, Vietnam War aircraft, Grumman aircraft

The Grumman S-2 Tracker is an american military aircraft built for operations against soviets submarines of the Cold War. Grumman sold it at various foreign countries like Brazil, Japan, or Turkey.

The Conair Firecat is a water bomber variant built in Canada.

[[Nord N-3202]]

CATEGORIES: French military aircraft, Nord aircraft

The Nord N-3202 is a French military training light aircraft. It was used only by the French Army.

[[Data collection]]

CATEGORIES: Knowledge

Data collection is the task of gathering and measuring data (information) in an orderly or systematic way. Researchers follow a formal plan for data collection to ensure that the information they collect has clear definitions, and is accurate. If you do not have clearly defined, accurate information, decisions you make using that information will not have validity.  

[[List of Kenyan scientists]]

CATEGORIES: Lists of scientists by nationality, Kenyan scientists

This is a list of noted scientists from Kenya.

[[Wojciech Krzemiński]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2017 deaths, Polish scientists, Astronomers, Polish educators, People from Warsaw

Wojciech Krzemiński (20 May 1933–5 August 2017) was a Polish astronomer and a retired professor of Nicolaus Copernicus Astronomical Center of Polish Academy of Sciences. He worked many years for the Carnegie Institution for Science Observatories. Krzemiński also discovered the optical companion of X-ray pulsar Centaurus X-3, which was named Krzemiński's Star in his honor.

He was also one of the first astronomers who correctly interpreted the nature of polar stars like AM Herculis.

Krzemiński died on 5 August 2017 in Warsaw at the age of 84.

[[Marián Varga]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Slovakian people, Composers, Organists

Marián Varga (January 29, 1947 – August 8, 2017) was a Slovak musician, composer and organ player. He was born in Skalica, Czechoslovakia.

In 1979, he began a solo career. Among other achievements, he became a pioneer of absolute improvisation (real-time composition) in Slovakia. In the meantime he continued to contribute to popular music. His work with Pavol Hammel led to five successful albums and to the first rock musical in Slovakia.

[[Loir]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of France, Centre-Val de Loire, Pays de la Loire

The Loir is a river in central France. It is a left tributary of the Sarthe. It flows through two regions of France: Centre-Val de Loire and Pays de la Loire

The Eure-et-Loir and Loir-et-Cher departments are named after this river.

[[Vendôme]]

CATEGORIES: Subprefectures in France, Communes in Loir-et-Cher

Vendôme is a commune in central French, and is a subprefecture in the Loir-et-Cher department. It is also the capital of the arrrondissement of Vendôme and the administrative centre of the Vendôme canton.

Vendôme is one of the main towns along the Loir river. It is the third largest city of the department after Blois and Romorantin-Lanthenay.

[[Nyanzapithecus alesi]]

CATEGORIES: Apes

Nyanzapithecus alesi was an ape that lived thirteen million years ago in Africa.  A complete skull of an infant was  recovered and reported in 2017.

Scientists say it is from around the time when apes originated.

[[Questacon]]

CATEGORIES: Museums in Australia

Questacon – the National Science and Technology Centre is on the southern shore of Lake Burley Griffin, an artificial lake in Canberra, ACT, Australia. 

It has more than 200 interactive exhibits relating to science and technology. It was designed to expose children to science. It is suitable for visitors of all ages.

[[Krzysztof Książek]]

CATEGORIES: 1992 births, Living people, Polish pianists, People from Kraków, Polish composers

Krzysztof Książek (born 5 August 1992) is a Polish classical pianist. He was born in Krakow, Poland. He is a winner of highest prizes at national and international piano competitions. His nomation is Polityka Passport Award for Classical Music. Since 2005, he has trained with Stefan Wojtas, first at music secondary school, now as a student of the Feliks Nowowiejski Academy of Music in Bydgoszcz. He has won prizes in Polish and international competitions, including the Ricard Vines in Leida, Spain, the Lviv international competitions in Ukraine, the "Città di Avezzano" in Italy (2011, First Prize) and the Polish Frédéric Chopin Piano Competition in Warsaw (2011, Third Prize; 2015, Second Prize ex aequo), XV International Pianist Ricard Vines (Lleida, Spain 2009), The International Chopin Piano Competition (Lviv, Ukraine 2010), VI Concorso Internazionale Pianistico "Citta di Avezzano" (Avezzano, He participated in the 67th International Chopin Festival in Duszniki-Zdrój, the 18th International Festival of Young Winners of Silesian Music Contests, 5th National Promotion Festival "August Talents" He is a scholarship recipient of the "Sapere Auso" Malopolska Foundation, the Prime Minister, the Ministry of Culture and National Heritage, and the Pro Musica Bona Foundation.

On his preliminary round he was admitted as ex-aequo winner of the 2nd Prize on the 2015 Polish National Fryderyk Chopin Piano Competition in Warsaw. He was stopped in the third stage of the XVII International Chopin Piano Competition in 2015. Although Krzysztof Książek was not qualified for the finals of the Chopin Competition, Andrzej Sułek believes that his name may return to the competition in those days.

[[Rudno, Lesser Poland Voivodeship]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Poland

Rudno is a village in the administrative district of Gmina Krzeszowice in Kraków County, Lesser Poland Voivodeship in southern Poland. It is approximately 6 southwest of Krzeszowice and 26 west of the regional capital Kraków.

[[Fendels]]

CATEGORIES: Cities and towns in Tyrol (state)

Fendels is a municipality in the district Landeck in the Austrian state of Tyrol. It is 13 km south of Landeck on the upper course of the Inn River.

[[Flerden]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities of Graubünden

Flerden (Flearda) is a municipality of the district Hinterrhein in the canton of Graubünden in Switzerland.

[[Breithorn]]

CATEGORIES: Alps, Mountains of Italy, Mountains of Switzerland, Geography of Valais

The Breithorn is a mountain range of the Pennine Alps with its highest peak of the same name (but also called Breithorn (Western Summit)). It is on the border between Switzerland and Italy. It lies on the main chain of the Alps. It is a halfway between the Matterhorn and Monte Rosa and east of the Theodul Pass. The nearest settlements are Zermatt (Valais) and St-Jacques (Aosta Valley).

The Breithorn was first climbed in 1813 by Henry Maynard (climber), Joseph-Marie Couttet, Jean Gras, Jean-Baptiste Erin and Jean-Jacques Erin.

[[Eastlake, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Ohio

Eastlake is a city in Ohio in the United States. It is in Lake County.

[[Lake County, Ohio]]

CATEGORIES: 1840s establishments in Ohio, 1840 establishments in the United States, Ohio counties

Lake County is a county of Ohio in the United States. In 2010, 230,041 people lived there. The county seat is Painesville.

[[Geispitzen]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Haut-Rhin

Geispitzen is a commune. It is found in the Haut-Rhin department of eastern France.

[[Geiswasser]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Haut-Rhin

Geiswasser is a commune. It is found in the Haut-Rhin department of eastern France.

It is 6 km south of Breisach and 25 km southeast of Colmar.

[[Pizza Delivery (SpongeBob SquarePants)]]

CATEGORIES: SpongeBob SquarePants episodes, 1999 television episodes

"Pizza Delivery" is the first part of the 5th episode of SpongeBob SquarePants. It was first broadcast on Nickelodeon on August 14, 1999. The episode is about SpongeBob and Squidward delivering a pizza in a desert.

[[Rock Bottom (SpongeBob SquarePants)]]

CATEGORIES: SpongeBob SquarePants episodes, 2000 television episodes

"Rock Bottom" is the 2nd part of the 17th episode of SpongeBob SquarePants. It was first broadcast on Nickelodeon on March 15, 2000. The episode is about SpongeBob getting stuck in a dark city named Rock Bottom. The episode was watched by about 2.1 million people when it was first broadcast. 

[[Heinz F. Dressel]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2017 deaths, German theologians, German historians, Writers from Bavaria

Heinz Friedrich Dressel (28 September 1929 – 4 August 2017) was a German theologian and writer. He was born in Marktredwitz, Germany. His work focused on human rights and the history of Brazil. He wrote many books about the history of Latin America and views of Christianity. 

Dressel died on 4 August 2017 in Nuremberg, Germany at the age of 87.

[[Rius]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2017 deaths, Political activists, Cartoonists, Mexican writers

Eduardo Humberto del Río García (June 20, 1934 – August 8, 2017), better known by his pen name Rius, was a Mexican intellectual, political cartoonist and writer. He was born in Zamora, Michoacán. He was a supporter of the Cuban revolution and was a strong critic of Fidel Castro's rule. His best known works were Cuba for Beginners and It's a Pity, Cuba.

Rius died on 8 August 2017 in Cuernavaca, Morelos at the age of 83.

[[Cuernavaca]]

CATEGORIES: Capital cities in Mexico, Municipalities of Mexico

Cuernavaca (Cuernavaca.ogg; "near the woods", Kuaujnawak.ogg) is the capital and largest city of the state of Morelos in Mexico. It was established by the Olmec, "the mother culture" of Mesoamerica, approximately 3,200 years ago and is designated as the archaeological site of Gualupita I . The city is located south of Mexico City, from which it may be reached after a drive of approximately 1½ hours using the D-95 Freeway.

[[Giancarlo Giannini]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, Living people, Actors who played in James Bond movies, Italian movie actors, Italian television actors, Italian voice actors

Giancarlo Giannini (dʒaŋˈkarlo dʒanˈniːni; born 1 August 1942) is an Italian actor and voice-over artist. In 1976, he starred in Seven Beauties, for which he was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Actor. He dubbed Jack Nicholson's voice in the Italian release of both The Shining and Batman; he is the official Italian dubber of Al Pacino.

In 2009, Giannini received a star on the Italian Walk of Fame in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.

[[List of communes of the Province of Rieti]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Lazio, Lists of settlements in Europe

The following is a list of the 73 comuni of the Province of Rieti, Lazio, in Italy.

[[Patricio Echegaray]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from pancreatic cancer, Argentine politicians, Communists

Patricio Echegaray (17 October 1946 – 9 August 2017) was an Argentine politician. He was born in San José de Jáchal, Argentina. He served as Secretary General of the Communist Party of Argentina from 1986 until his death in 2017. Before, he served as the 26th Secretary General of the Juvenile Communist Federation from 1980 through 1985.

Echegaray died of pancreatic cancer on 9 August 2017 in Buenos Aires at the age of 70.

[[Ken Roberts (rugby league)]]

CATEGORIES: 2017 deaths, English rugby union players, Sportspeople from Lancashire

Kenneth "Ken" Roberts (died 8 August 2017) was an English professional rugby league footballer. He played in the 1950s, 1960s, and 1970s, playing at representative level for Great Britain and Lancashire, and at club level for Swinton, Halifax, Bradford Northern, Rochdale Hornets and Salford.

Roberts was born in Atherton, Lancashire. He died on 8 August 2017.

[[Janet Seidel]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from ovarian cancer, Cancer deaths in Sydney, Australian singers, Australian musicians, Australian educators, Jazz pianists

Janet Seidel (28 May 1955 – 8 August 2017) was an Australian singer, pianist and educator. She was born in Cummins, South Australia.

Her albums, recorded with her brother bassist David Seidel, have been nominated for prizes such as the ARIA Music Awards. Her album Moon of Manakoora won the Bell Award for Best Australian Jazz Vocal Album in 2006. She was a music teacher at Sydney Girls High School.

Seidel died on 8 August 2017 from ovarian cancer at her home in Sydney, New South Wales at the age of 62.

[[Ruth Pfau]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from cardiovascular disease, Physicians, Activists, Nuns, Pakistani people, People from Leipzig

Sister Dr Ruth Katherina Martha Pfau (9 September 1929 – 10 August 2017) was a German-Pakistani physician and nun of the Society of Daughters of the Heart of Mary. She devoted nearly 50 years of her life to fighting leprosy in Pakistan. She was born in Leipzig, Germany. She founded the Marie Adelaide Leprosy Centre. 

In 2015, Pfau was awarded the Staufer Medal - the highest award of the German state of Baden-Württemberg.

Pfau died at a hospital in Karachi, Pakistan on 10 August 2017 from complications of heart disease at the age of 87.

[[2016 United States presidential election in West Virginia]]

CATEGORIES: History of West Virginia, 2016 United States presidential election by state

The 2016 United States presidential election in West Virginia was held on 8 November 2016. It was part of the 2016 United States presidential election, in which all other states plus the District of Columbia voted.

On 10 May 2016, the state also voted for who they wanted to be the nominee of their respective parties.

[[Otto Schenk]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, Living people, Austrian movie actors, Austrian stage actors, Austrian movie directors, Actors from Vienna

Otto Schenk (born June 12, 1930) is an Austrian actor, and theater and opera director. He was born in Vienna, Austria. His career began in 1953. Schenk has appeared in over 30 movies (mostly in German). He is known for his lavish, realist, traditionalist stagings at the Metropolitan Opera, most notably his production of Richard Wagner's four-opera epic Der Ring des Nibelungen. 

Schenk is currently starring in the stage adaptation of Lily Brett's Chuzpe at the Kammerspiele Theatre in Vienna.

Schenk is known for his movie roles in Always Trouble with the Reverend (1972) and in Reigen (1973). His best known stage role was in Arabella (1977).

[[Jacob Rothschild, 4th Baron Rothschild]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, Living people, Bankers, British billionaires, British businesspeople, British philanthropists, British Jews, Jewish billionaires, Jewish businesspeople, Jewish philanthropists

Nathaniel Charles Jacob Rothschild, 4th Baron Rothschild OM GBE (born 29 April 1936) is a British investment banker and philanthropist of Jewish descent. He is a member of the prominent Rothschild banking family. He is also Honorary President of the Institute for Jewish Policy Research. His net worth is at US $5 billion as of 2015.

Rothschild is a known philanthropist who donates his money to art and culture centers. He was Chairman of Trustees of the National Gallery from 1985 to 1991, and from 1992 to 1998, chairman of the National Heritage Memorial Fund.

[[2016 United States presidential election in New Mexico]]

CATEGORIES: History of New Mexico, 2016 United States presidential election by state

The 2016 United States presidential election in New Mexico was held on 8 November 2016. It was part of the 2016 United States presidential election, in which all other states plus the District of Columbia voted.

On 7 June 2016, the state also voted for who they wanted to be the nominee of their respective parties.

[[2016 United States presidential election in Arizona]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s in Arizona, 2016 United States presidential election by state

The 2016 United States presidential election in Arizona was held on 8 November 2016. It was part of the 2016 United States presidential election, in which all other states plus the District of Columbia voted.

On 22 March and 5 April 2016, the state also voted for who they wanted to be the nominee of their respective parties.

[[List of largest stars]]

CATEGORIES: Lists of stars

Below is a list of the largest stars,  so far discovered, ordered by radius. The unit of measurement used is the radius of the Sun (696,392 km; 432,717.927 mi).

[[Choe Yong-rim]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, Living people, North Korean politicians

Choe Yong-rim (KCNA: Choe Yong Rim, Korean: 최영림, born 20 November 1930) was the Premier (naegak ch’ongri, 내각 총리) of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (commonly known as North Korea) from June 2010 to April 2013 and Workers' Party of Korea central committee presidium member since September 2010.

Choe has been described by The New York Times as a "KWP insider" and a "friend of Kim Jong-Il's family." He is honorary vice-president of the Presidium of the Supreme People's Assembly, the country's parliament.

[[Klosterneuburg]]

CATEGORIES: Cities and towns in Lower Austria

Klosterneuburg is an Austrian town in the Tulln District in the Industrieviertel region of Lower Austria. It had about 27,000 people in 2016.

Klosterneuburg lies almost entirely south of the Danube River and borders the city of Vienna in the southeast. 

It is well-known for its winegrowing.

[[Velino]]

CATEGORIES: Rivers of Italy

The Velino is a river in central Italy that flows through the Lazio and Umbria regions but flows mainly through the Lazio region. It is the main tributary of the Nera river which is tributary of the Tiber river.

[[Rieti]]

CATEGORIES: Capital cities in Italy, Cities in Lazio

Rieti is a comune and city in the Lazio region, in central Italy. Rieti is the capital of the province of Rieti and of the historical region of Sabina.

[[Francisco Núñez Olivera]]

CATEGORIES: 1904 births, 2018 deaths, Spanish military people, Spanish supercentenarians

Francisco Núñez Olivera (13 December 1904 – 29 January 2018), age 113 years, 47 days, for a brief time was recognized as the oldest man in the world. He was born at Extremadura, and joined the army at 19 to fight in the Rif War.

Núñez Olivera had his kidney removed when he was 90 and a cataract operation aged 98, and is a veteran of the Spanish Civil War. He was nicknamed "Marchena" after Pepe Marchena, due to his resemblance to the singer. With the death of Israeli supercentenarian Yisrael Kristal on 11 August 2017, Núñez became the worlds oldest living man. He died on 29 January 2018.

[[What About Us]]

CATEGORIES: Pink songs, 2017 songs, Dance songs, Ballads, Dance-pop songs

"What About Us" is a song by American singer-songwriter Pink, taken from her seventh studio album, Beautiful Trauma.  The song was released on August 10, 2017, along with the preorder of Beautiful Trauma.  The song is a dance ballad that speaks of people who are forgotten or left out.

The song reached number one in Australia and Switzerland, while reaching the top twenty around the world. It reached number three in the UK, number six in Canada, and number 13 on the Billboard Hot 100 in the US.

It was certified platinum in the US for sales and shipments of one million copies there.

[[Eberhard von Koerber]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2017 deaths, German businesspeople, People from Lower Saxony

Eberhard "Ebbo" von Koerber (11 June 1938 – 3 August 2017) was a German manager. He was a member of the Board of Management of BMW. He was responsible for sales and marketing from 1984 to 1986. Between 1988 and 1998, he was responsible for the activities of Asea Brown Boveri in Europe, the Middle East and Africa as Vice President of the Group Executive in Zurich. From 2007 to 2012, he was co-president of the Club of Rome.

Von Koerber died on 3 August 2017 at the age of 79.

[[Waldemar Schreckenberger]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2017 deaths, German academics, German lawyers, People from Ludwigshafen, Politicians from Rhineland-Palatinate, Politicians of the Christian Democratic Union of Germany

Waldemar Schreckenberger (12 November 1929 – 4 August 2017) was a German lawyer, professor emeritus, and  politician. He was born in Ludwigshafen. He was a member of the Christian Democratic Union of Germany (CDU).

From 1981 to 1982, he served as Minister of Justice of Rhineland-Palatinate and thereafter as Head of the German Chancellery under Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

He died in Heidelberg at the age of 87.

[[Wolfgang H. Berger]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2017 deaths, American academics, American geologists, German scientists, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Oceanographers, People from Bavaria

Wolfgang "Wolf" Helmut Berger (5 October 1937 – 6 August 2017) was a German-American oceanographer, geologist, micropaleontologist and emeritus professor at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography, University of California, San Diego. He was born in Erlangen, Germany. His research interests comprise "micropaleontology, marine sedimentation, ocean productivity, carbon cycle, ocean history, climate history, and history of oceanography."

Berger died in San Diego, California on 6 August 2017 at the age of 79.

[[Abdulhussain Abdulredha]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2017 deaths, Kuwaiti people, Movie actors, Writers, Stage actors

Abdulhussain Abdulredha (15 July 1939 – 11 August 2017), (عبد الحسين عبد الرضا ar) was a Kuwaiti actor, famous and prominent in the Middle East in particular. Abdulredha is best known for his personality of sarcastic humor that made a mockery of the Arab situation comedy template. He was one of the founders of the Arab theater in 1961 and the National Theatre in 1976, as the year 1984 established a special brigade Theatre Arts.

On 11 August 2017, Abdulredha died in London aged 78.

[[Chris Hesketh]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2017 deaths, English rugby union players, People from Wigan, Sportspeople from Greater Manchester

Chris Hesketh MBE (1944 – 10 August 2017) from Wigan, was an English professional Rugby League World Cup winning footballer of the 1960s, and 1970s. He played at representative level for Great Britain, England, and Lancashire representative, and at club level for Wigan and Salford. He was born in Wigan, England.

[[Terele Pávez]]

CATEGORIES: Goya Award winners, 1939 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Spanish movie actors, Spanish television actors, People from Bilbao

Teresa Marta Ruiz Penella (29 July 1939 – 11 August 2017) better known as Terele Pávez was a Spanish actress. She appeared in more than ninety movies since 1954. She was born in Bilbao (Biscay), Spain. She was known for her roles in The Holy Innocents, La Celestina and in El Bar. She won a Goya Award in 2003.

Pávez died on 11 August 2017 from a stroke at the age of 78.

[[Ana María Vela Rubio]]

CATEGORIES: 1901 births, 2017 deaths, People from Andalusia, Spanish supercentenarians

Ana María Vela Rubio (29 October 1901 – 15 December 2017), was a Spanish supercentenarian. She was the oldest verified Spaniard ever from 6 June 2016 when, aged 114 years, 221 days until her death. and was also the oldest Spanish-born person starting in 4 April 2017 when, aged 115 years, 157 days.

Vela Rubio was also the third oldest living person in the world. She became the oldest European since the death of oldest person Emma Morano on 15 April 2017. She is the third oldest person ever from Europe, after Jeanne Calment and Emma Morano.

Vela Rubio was born 29 October 1901 in Puente Genil, Andalusia. She used to work as a dressmaker. She never married her partner as her parents did not agree to their marrying, but the couple had two children. Her daughter, also named Ana, lives with her. She died on 15 December 2017.

[[Frank Bacon (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1864 births, 1922 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Cardiovascular disease deaths in Chicago, Burials at Oak Woods Cemetery, American stage actors, American playwrights, Actors from California, Writers from California

Frank Bacon (January 16, 1864 – November 19, 1922), was an American character actor and playwright. After years of relative low success he achieved great success as he entered the twilight of his career. The 1918 play Lightnin', which Bacon co-wrote and starred in, set a Broadway record for the day of 1,291 performances and was still going strong on tour after more than 700 shows when Bacon was forced to bow out due to fatigue.

A week after his retirement, Bacon died of a heart attack in Chicago on November 19, 1922 at the age of 

[[Adolfo Pérez Esquivel]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, Argentine writers, Critics, Activists, Argentine painters, Argentine sculptors, People from Buenos Aires, Argentine Nobel Prize winners, Argentine politicians, Human rights activists, Nobel Peace Prize winners, Nonviolence advocates

PeaceAdolfo Pérez Esquivel (born November 26, 1931) is an Argentine activist, community organizer, art painter, writer and sculptor. He was the recipient of the 1980 Nobel Peace Prize for his criticism of the Argentina's last civil-military dictatorship (1976-1983). He was detained, tortured, and held without trial for 14 months; during that period he also received, among other distinctions, the Pope John XXIII Peace Memorial.

[[Flag of Croatia]]

CATEGORIES: Croatia, National flags, Establishments in Croatia, 1990 establishments in Europe

The Flag of Croatia is three equal size red, white and blue horizontal stripes. In the middle is the coat of arms of Croatia. It was adopted on 21 December 1990.

[[Christian Kern]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, Living people, Austrian journalists, Chancellors of Austria, Chief executives, Civil servants, Politicians from Vienna

Christian Kern (born January 4, 1966 in Vienna) is an Austrian politician of the Social Democratic Party of Austria (SPÖ). He was the leader of the SPÖ from June 25, 2016 to September 25, 2018. He was replaced by Pamela Rendi-Wagner.

Kern was Chancellor of Austria from May 17, 2016 to December 18, 2017. His predecessor was fellow party member Werner Faymann, his successor is Sebastian Kurz (ÖVP). 

After studying journalism and communication at the University of Vienna, he worked as a business journalist and a civil servant. Afterwards he worked at the Verbund AG, the biggest supplier of electricity in Austria. He became chief of the ÖBB, the federal railways of Austria, in 2010.

[[Bludenz (district)]]

CATEGORIES: Districts of Vorarlberg

The Bludenz District (Bezirk Bludenz) is an administrative district (Bezirk) of the state of Vorarlberg, Austria.

It has an area of 1,287.63 km². As of 2012 about 61,407 people lived there.

The administrative center of the district is Bludenz.

[[Gosheim]]

Gosheim is a municipality in Tuttlingen in the state of Baden-Württemberg, Germany.

[[Jestetten]]

Jestetten is a municipality of the district Waldshut in the state of Baden-Württemberg in Germany. It is on the border with Switzerland.

[[Segun Bucknor]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2017 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Guitarists, Journalists, Nigerian musicians, Nigerian writers, People from Lagos, Pianists, Pop musicians, Soul musicians

Segun Bucknor (29 March 1946 – 11 August 2017) was a Nigerian journalist and musician active during the 1960s. He was a pianist and guitarist specializing in genres ranging from Soul music to Pop music and to Funk. He was the father of media personality Tosyn Bucknor. He was the bandleader of Segun Bucknor and the Assembly. The group recorded a couple of soul songs such as Lord Give Me Soul and I Will Love You No Matter How.

Bucknor died in Lagos on 11 August 2017 after suffering from multiple strokes at the age of 71. At the time of his death, he was suffering from hypertension and diabetes.

[[Bobby Ray Inman]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, Living people, Admirals, Military people from Texas, Politicians from Texas, US Republican Party politicians

Bobby Ray Inman (born April 4, 1931) is a retired United States admiral. He held many important positions in the U.S. Intelligence Community. 

He served as Director of Naval Intelligence from September 1974 to July 1976, then moved to the Defense Intelligence Agency where he served as Vice Director until 1977. He next became the Director of the National Security Agency. Inman held this post until 1981. His last major position was as the Deputy Director of Central Intelligence, a post he held from February 12, 1981 to June 10, 1982.

Inman was announced as President Bill Clinton's choice to replace Les Aspin as Secretary of Defense on December 16, 1993, receiving broad bipartisan support. He accepted the post at first, but withdrew his nomination during a press conference on January 18, 1994.

[[NoFap]]

CATEGORIES: Organizations, Sexuality, Anti-pornography activists

NoFap or fapstinence is a group that tries to stop masturbating and watching porn. The NoFap website was founded in 2011 by Alexander Rhodes. People who try out the programme sometimes call themselves fapstinents, fapstronauts or nofappers. Some people try out the NoFap plan because it makes them feel more confident. Along with red pillers, incels, MGTOWs and PUA it is a part of the manosphere.

Flims is a municipality of the district Imboden in the Swiss canton of Graubünden.

Kurt "Kuddel" Liebrecht (born 24 December 1936 in Stendal) is a former East German footballer. He was a midfielder.

Liebrecht played for 1. FC Lok Stendal. He also played for the East Germany national football team.

[[News Radio UK]]

CATEGORIES: Radio stations in the United Kingdom

News Radio UK is a British digital radio station that is owned by Radio NewsHub, Radio Today and Radio Response. News Radio UK features news, weather, traffic, sports, showbiz and business summaries on a continuous loop. In addition to its availability on DAB (in Aldershot, Cambridge, Glasgow, Norwich and Portsmouth), the station's programming is streamed live on the network's website, and through apps for Apple, Android, and Kindle devices; plus on Radioplayer and Tunein.

The national flag of the Czech Republic (státní vlajka České republiky) has two equal horizontal bands of white (top) and red with a blue isosceles triangle based on the hoist side.

[[Peter Weibel (cyclist)]]

Peter Weibel (14 September 1950 – 9 August 2017) was a German cyclist. He was born in Hockenheim, Germany. He competed for West Germany at the 1972 Summer Olympics and the 1976 Summer Olympics.

Weibel died of cancer on 9 August 2017 at the age of 66.
